title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. What did I like? That that it was free. What I don't like? As I've seen several others say I also agree that Bethesda wasted a lot of time and money working on this when they should have been working on more deserving games and I DON'T just mean ES VI I mean either Morrowind or especially Oblivion(which DID just turn 10 this year!)! All the other developers have been releasing anniversary editions for their 10 year old games so why didn't Oblivion get its anniversary edition?!Don't get me wrong yes it does look prettier but only by a VERY SLIGHT improvement over all the environmental mods I had in my Legendary Edition of the game. Is it worth paying full price for the Special Edition? ABSOLUTELY NOT! As several others have also noticed VERY FEW bugs were fixed. Also the other thing I've seen quite a few others complaining about is that using mods in the SE DOES DISABLE Steam achievements and console Trophies/Acheivements so if you care about that go pick up the older version for dirt cheap as using mods in THAT version unlocks them just fine.Btw why is it asking me to check a box if I received it free? Does that mean you readers are automatically supposed to discount my review just because I didn't pay for it? It was nice for Bethesda to do that for Steam users but it's extremely unfair to charge FULL PRICE for console users for a 5 year old game when I've seen the Legendary Edition going for $20 new!
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: it's just skyrim
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I really want to recommend this. It's Skyrim afterall. But this remaster in its current state is unrecommendable for only a few but meaningful reasons lack of additional content the oversight of at least borrowing some smart ideas from the mod community like HUD enhancements and BUGS A PLENTY.No new content disappointing.No updates to UI HUD or taking any great ideas from the mod community that were vast improvements.Visual graphics look good but I've seen comparable quality with the modding community.Bugs. holy hell. just crashes left and right. If this comes free for you have at it. It's gorgeous but honestly I can't believe the bugs giong on. It's nearly unplayable for any meaningful length of time. But if you're getting this brand spanking new I hope it goes better for you than me.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Not recommended because again Bethesda relies on other people to fix another one of their top products. I can manage with small bugs annoyances etc. but 1. Not being able to walk through open doors essentially preventing me from finishing quests without the use of the console or mods. Collisions are broken all around.2. Barnabas is EVEN MORE annoying which is almost impossible or so i thought.3. Random objects NPCs and animals can often be found floating in the air.4. Essenntially all of the original vanilla Skyrim bugs are transferred along with introducing new ones.(5. No achievements with or without mods or addons. EDIT I have not touched the game for a few days and suddently the achievements magically appeared go figure.)I'm sick of spending time fixing games instead of playing them. Considering that Fallout 4 is essentially Skyrim with guns and both games were released prior to Skyrim SE I thik Bethesda should do a better job working on a product rather than marketing it. After Thief 2014 i stopped bying Square Enix titles where you spend more time watching opening and closing windows rather than playing. Looks like my blacklist will be expading soon unless there are major improvemets in this product (Skyrim SE). Until then this review will stay negative.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Unless you got it for free I would avoid paying for it as it doesn't support Steam workshop. There's barely a difference and truly the original game with some mods looked way better. Do not spend money on this ''remastered'' version of a great game.

review: Product received for free. I don't know was this free? I mean I bought it just not this edition.This edition is for console players. If you have it on PC nothing they improved was needed and it was all done better by way of existing mods than they did here. Way to go for my PS4 playing friends though. They're all really excited for it to be coming back to a new generation.It doesn't look that much better in fact with the mods I already had on Skyrim this looks worse now so graphics aren't a reason to switch over.The mods are delivered via a Bethesda account rather than Steam Workshop. Not hard to use but a pain to log in when you can't paste into the password box and a completely unnecessaey change outside of folks on consoles.Using mods disables achievements. Adding hunger cold and other mods that make the game more difficult shouldn't treat you like you're cheating. I used one cheese mod on Skyrim a chest full of building materials for Hearthfire everything else I added was a realism mod. The only achievement I got without earning it was from playing with console commands rather than adding a mod.Stick with Skyrim add some good mods and leave this "Special Edition" to console players.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

There are shops I lose access to because vampires killed the merchants. Quest lines endangered by vamps killing NPCs involved. The random overpowered vampire attacks are the one and only reason that DAWNGUARD SUCKS. My message to the devloper fix the random vamp problem or let us disable Dawnguard!
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. + its free (My thanks is tempered by knowing that Bethesda knows there is nothing worth charging for here so they gave it away in the hopes to entice modders and users to port over to Bethesda.net and integrate with their console modding master plan)+ it does run quite fine on my aging HD7770 2GB (medium settings)+ does have prettier plants and better lighting/environment as advertised sometimes has the stutter/jerkiness that FO4 occasionaly exhibited for me..(not sure whats driving this..) it has hung up twice on exit almost forcing me to reboot my PC until it magically self resolved and returned control to me (worse behavior that my legendary edition and same kind of behavior I saw in FO4) All SKSE/FNIS based mods are toast for now RE this version doubt a lot of them will be ported because a lot of modders are moved on (real life or diff games) so thats a deal breaker. Legendary Edition + a few mods nets the equivalent or better look/feel as SSE After booting into SSE I remembered why I modded it (ugly faces and horrible console based UI) ugly face textures No SkyUI / iHUD no new content no fixes from unofficial patchTLDR * Negative review because they only released this to further Bethesda.net and entice mod makers to port to it. * Owners of Legendary edition can install 5 mods and get better performance and visuals (or close enough).* I have 4k hours in Skyrim and I LOVE the ES series but Bethesda is way in the weeds here. Come back guys...you done f'd it up.Edit Spelling/grammar

review: Product received for free. A welcome improvement but still room for improvement.I feel like graphically Skyrim SE is what 2011 Skyrim should have been a built in ENB (or very nearly so) better lighting high res textures depth of field (maybe even a little parallax?). The character models are oh kay good enough to play but still lacking the polish of say Mass Effect. The draw distance is still less than great and the water looks like flowing gel but as shipped it's 85% of the way there.The game also has considerable under the hood improvement. It opens in a near instant. Not a single crash thus far. Alt+tab works! (TOOK LONG ENOUGH.) Whiterun loaded in 2.5 *seconds*. I've never seen the framerate so consistently high or loading screens so consistently short. Took 10 years since 64 bit was common but it's here at last. Bravo.Gameplay wise Skyrim SE is still 2011 Skyrim through and through. It was actually shocking to remember what that was like as I'm coming from my heavily modded Frostfall+Requiem+EGO+Warzones hardcore gameplay installation of the original. I just beat Helgen on my first try not my 30th. Everything thus far has been a cake walk. Which reminds me of this article ( http //www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video games/columns/firstperson/9265 Skyrim is Soulless ) and underscores sadly that original Skyrim as shipped is a sort of Potempkin village lots of pretty things to look at but it's all only skin deep. No real challenge no real choices or consequences. This new Skyrim SE *needs* to be modded if for no other reason than to compensate for the critical gameplay elements that are still lacking.Which finally brings me to the missed opportunities. Though some bugs (crashing) appear to have been alleviated there is a huge and unforgivable missed opportunity. The unofficial patches at a minimum should have been included essential as they are and given that Bethesda has known about these bugs for years. It also would have been nice to have seen the original cut content (e.g. Pit Fighters Cutting Room Floor Civil War Overhaul Touring Carriages) restored the argument that they ran out of time doesn't cut it 5 years later. Other obvious deficiencies (slow horses no body in first person no multiple followers no open cities no built in SkyUI) still remain unaddressed as well. Perhaps the biggest missed opportunity is that at the dawn of the VR age there is no built in VR support. VR enthusiasts will rue this day for years.Should you get Skyrim SE? Of course. Skyrim (modded) is a great game. I just wish that after 5 years Skryim were finally shipping as it should have shipped 5 years ago.

review: Product received for free. When Skyrim first came out I had been so eager to play it. First owned it on the Xbox 360 for which it was a mind blowing experience instantly fell in love with the game. I moved to pc shortly after which only improved the game vastly. It was a medium level laptop I ran it on but the game still felt fresh.Coming back to it five years later there honestly isn't much that stands out. Obviously it's the same game plot and structure but nothing about the new and improved graphics and atmosphere feels well....new. The special edition has had a five year gap and between the two games many modders have managed to achieve even more than some of the new features...they simply don't reflect on what should have been. Sun shafts some slightly improved fire physics and redone textures are about as noticable as it gets (even though the hd textures were already available years prior). Other than that there doesn't appear to be anything visually striking. Even the poor NPC's still have those lifeless eyes...I mean if interection with them is such a big part of the game could they not have made them nicer to look at? This is a strictly Ultra settings opinion...as for the console users I have no doubt that things look nicer. The new edition for PCs however if you aren't recieving it for FREE is not in my opinion worth it. Mods within the Steam community are far more effective and will make you awe at the little details whereas the new edition will make you question the hype you spilled waiting for it to happen. It is a shame that such a title as Skyrim suffered of recent and I cannot honestly see myself delving into another 800 hours of gameplay.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: We only got it free since its PC that makes the mods. I bet they only did this to bring mods to console so that they can later bring back paid mods like they said they would. Most people look at it like "oh free candy" but nothing is truly free... This game just split the modding community and who knows what the big mods like skywind and skyblivion will do at this point.Old mods will be ported but not all. Problem is that we now have a split community with the more important mod projects lost in the middle. I cant say im happy with this the remastered looks worse then my old modded one and now im stuck wondering the fate of the major mod projects that would be remaking older TES games that actually NEED to be updated. Leave it to Bethesda to tear the community apart by trying to cash in on their modders. If you dont see whats going on.. open your eyes.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: It's Skyrim what to say? In short Great exploration insane ammount of quests killing people with swords axes maces magic 'n stuff overall a sh*t ton of stuff to do. Now about the Special Edition First of all it's either better or just as good as the Legendary Edition in every way.The graphics are overall nicer with new Godrays depth of field and much better shadows.Things like bugs and UI (excecpt the new "Mods" category in the main menu) were literally untouched (so no bug fixes gotta admit I'm disappointed).But the biggest change is the ditching of x32 and upgrade to x64 of the engine meaning it performs better than original Skyrim expecially in crowded areas even though the graphics are better aswell not to forget that this opens up a whole new level of high demanding mods to be created from a modding community still working after 5 years sicne the original Skyrim came out.But as conclusion I have to say I wouldn't buy it for 40 (got it for free like many others for having the normal game with all DLC) but if you get this as game key or on a sale for 30 or less I can highly recommend it (oh and if you don't own Skyrim at all it's worth the full price IMO).
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: disabled achievements when you have mods on wtf
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Back in 2011 when Skyrim was initially released I opted not to make the purchase. Yet here we are now in 2017. And this outstanding game has become my main go to game or only game. This game and series has so much going for it. With a brilliant story in depth lore too much of it in fact. As well as the exploration and RPG elements that are seen in game. Most favourably I'm in love that you create a character and that character can be whatever and do whatever you wish to do. Whether it be to ignore the main questline which is good but a little on the short side for me personally. With hundreds of diversions and distractions along the way is unbelievable. And I can see myself playing the Elder Scroll's games for many years to come. Playing Skyrim had also seen the purchase of Oblivion and ESO. Just to get a taste of the Elder Scroll's franchise as a whole. And I am amazed. Thank you Bethesda for bringing me THE game that I've been looking for. Ted )
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: 8/10 for the graphical updates. It looks a lot better than vanilla skyrim (despite claims to the contrary). The vastly improved shadows are the real improvement here. At noon on a sunny day is where it's most apparent it's not the flickery shadowed mess it used to be. Other times of day have big improvements too and sunsets are beautiful (if a bit overblown).The Volumetric Lighting/Godrays are overdone in foggy weather especially in the rift but also stunning at times the throat of the world or markarth looming over you and casting a huge shadow is impressive. As for DoF I turned depth of field down (but not off) because my character isnt myopic.Also.... Precipitation occlusion has been added! This is the biggest thing for me in regards to the updates real shelter they didnt capitalise on that and add more violent weather however which brings me onto....3/10 for effort.I know bethesda never said this would be anything more than a graphical update. But I really think it was a missed opportunity to really reboot this game and fix blatent issues and gameplay problems. Bugs? Gaps in magic gameplay? (backpedal and die) Light vs Heavy armour gameplay? Archery? Many people have learnt from 5 years of modding and improvements and the games failings really came to light over the years (I would have happily payed for a reboot like that).Finally. The game runs super smooth feels great and loads quickly. Even with the open cities mod my game runs at a fairly stable 60 fps on my old GTX760 high settings... the modding potential for this improvement to performance cant be understated.PS Hurry up with the public CK release please.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Great remaster.The graphics have been updated to a more modern look with the usual effects you would expect from modern games (DOF good lighting good shadows large draw distance etc).Some users seem to be comparing the Special Edition to their heavily modded Skyrim but Bethesda was remastering Vanilla Skyrim not Joe Blogs ENB and Reshade fueled and 100+ modded Skyrim. Common sense needs to be used here.The game is now 64bit as well meaning that future modding will be a lot easier and should have much less problems like CTD's.If you're a huge Skyrim fan this Special Edition has turned you beloved game into a more modern and relevant game. Also if you're a huge Skyrim fan you probably got the gaem for free so what more do we need!.A great game just got better.

review: You can basically do anything you want to do in this game. I think there are two main quests and a TON of side quests that will have you playing the game for hours it has a couple of good side quests too but the best one is probably the one with the Dark Brotherhood so make sure you choose to cooperate with them (i destroyed them on my first save file lol). The character customization on this game is amazing you can buy land build houses marry someone adopt kids improve and craft your own weapons and armor and if you've maxed out your pickpocket perk tree you can strip naked npcs without them noticing lol. There's also a lot of mods you can use too that are fun. Would definitely recommend!
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. The same great game with a updated engine that doesn't have a 3GB ram cap fixed shadowing and lightning depth of field. Don't really understand why the reviews are mixed. Bethesda never promised a completely redone Skyrim not sure why you are expecting updated textures or possibly some new content.The engine alone makes this a great edition as with a bigger ram cap you can support more mods not just more mods but not expect to crash every 15 minutes. Don't like how the game looks in the SE? Install your favorite ENB and or graphic mods without really effecting performance. Install all your same favorite Skyrim mods that you know and love (when they are updated) with increased performance. Best of all most people got it for free. I am one person who is not going to complain about a free upgrade.

review: I didn't get on the Skyrim band wagon during its initial release. I had never heard of the Elder Scrolls series and I thought it was some complex rigid RPG like I had played many times before.After finally getting pushed into it despite attempting to resist the hype it's grown on me significantly. Primarily the freedom this game allows. Technically you can play the main story line and progress as if it were a rigidly constructed RPG but (especially with mods) the game almost adapts to your play style.Many people I know have never even "beat" Skyrim in terms of completing the main story. Many of those people have restarted characters countless times just to try out something different this go around. The fact that you can have so much fun without linear progression is what ended up making this game so enjoyable for me.

AFTER YEARS.I can't recommend it. Definitely don't buy it.Bethesda are now Blacklisted I am sick and tired of having to go to Modders for simple game fixs that Bethesda themselves should be fixing.They are hands down the laziest company to date.I see EA at a higher regard Bethesda used to be my favourite Company.They just on their customers over and over majority are just used to it as they've become content with letting Bethesda sit on the backs of Modders and let them fix all their games.Let me simplify this they are a game company that don't fix 5 year old bugs but still release a "Special Edition" with the exact same BUGS.. review: Product received for free. Too bad there is no rating option in middle. Like ''it depends''. Skyrim with dlc's (and even without them) is really amazing game. Tons of missions areas to explore and pure fantasy fun i would even say its one of the best games to start your adventure with gaming overall. But we are talking about special edition and what it is specially on the start. It adds in game moding menu on standard we must use steam workshop. Some graphical updates and after my comparing they are not really big maybe on screenshots or with everythink on ultra the light is better but on high it looks only bit better no updated textures tho and some technical updates. Its nothink new in the game. Not even new achievements. For those who got it for free its fun way to play it again or finally finish the game but for new players the standard skyrim with dlcs is much cheaper and less demanding version. Overall i am still giving it positive this is one of the best RPG games ever made and with some future updates it should be more stable. On the start game didnt even worked for me so for anyone whose game starts for like 2 seconds but dont show up launch and closes after here is insturction how to fix it.1. Go into folder where you installed game 2. Go to _CommonRedist folder.3. Go to VcRedist folder4. Run installer and press repair.5. If it doesnt work uninstall and install again.Aaaand it crashed after 2 hours. Just Bethesda things...

review: Product received for free. Other than 64 bit support Skyrim Remastered brings little to the table in terms of improvement over the original. Unless you got it for free I would avoid paying 40 dollars for what is still essentially a five year old game bugs and all. IF HOWEVER you are in the minority that hasn't bought Skyrim until now I would recommend it because what it does bring to the table is the ability to mod the game to a much greater extent than the original which is absolutely essential for Skyrim. And you get all the DLC which is another plus.What disappoints me the most is the lack of effort on Bethesda to improve some of the major complaints from the original Skyrim. Just another "Remastered" cash grab to exploit console users like we saw with Bioshock. Hopefully we can nip this type of publisher behavior in the bud before this becomes a recurring issue.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: TESV SSE is a beautifully optimized version of the original Skyrim. Some people will disagree with this but there are specific reasons for that. Let's take a look at some of them.For newcomers to the game this is the place to start. It features numerous improvements to lighting and overall experience when compared to the original (the unmodded special edition is superior to the unmodded original and addresses some known issues of the latter). Do expect a few bugs when playing the early builds especially weird NPC glitches as expected of a recent remake of such a complex platform.HOWEVER... if you are a veteran of the original one used to playing the optimized and modded version of Skyrim you will probably feel that the Special Edition is lackluster or even a downright downgrade. Why? Because you are used to 3rd party changes that took years to fine tune. What one needs to take into account is that SE is the new platform upon which future mods will be built... many modders if not most have already stopped working on the standard platform to begin porting efforts and SE development. This means that in a few months time the modded version of the Special Edition will (likely) be far superior to the standard one and that alone is more than enough to recommend it. Conclusion It's a must buy for long term players of Skyrim although still raw... some patience will be required for it to be modded enough to shine like the hidden gem it really is.

review: Product received for free. I've got to say that at this point in time this version of Skyrim is not worth having. This has more bugs and appears to be broken. If I use the launcher to set the games resolution I get 40 50 fps. If it set the resolution manually in the ini I get 130 144 (both tested with Vsync disabled). Also the game will only let me select 720p on a 1080p monitor. So here is my performance breakdown Running 1280x720 40 50fpsRunning 1920x1080 30 50fpsRunning 1280x1024 130 144fps or solid 60 with Vsync(Vsync is necessary to not break physics)

DO NOT BUYI might not have played very much of the game but there were certain things early on that can show that there aren't going to be any changes later down that line. The game looked washed out much like the original the textures were only minimally changed and there are still audio bugs. I'm not sure if it's my PC but I could only get 30 FPS playing this my thought is that it might be capped but I'm not certain. I love Skyrim I've played thorugh the game several times on PC and console but it would be better to not spend money on this and instead buy the original Skyrim and It's DLC if you don't have it already. Pack the original with mods and download the FREE DLC that will get you the same quality as Special Edition and it will be a way better experience then this. review: If bethesda think that paid mods will be accepted then they should re think their buisness model I have enjoyed my time mostly in skyrim SE but i made it through the tutorial and then i had to add mods the game is playable without them but texture mods and the unoficial patch being a few mods I would struggle without the fact that i need an unofficial patch to play the game without bugs shows to me why bethesda did not spend as much time as they should have making SE an ultimate edition of skyrim. Bethesda need's to step up there game if i want mods i use the nexus mod platform because it is so much better and well made it is less glitchy and has MORE MODS that are ALL FREE none of them are locked behind a paywall. I think i should have gotten legendary edition it has more mods and is cheaper it has no paid mods to make me want to uninstall the game I think that if you are debating between Special Edition and Legendary Edition you should get legendary and get access to amazing mods like playing multiplayer with your friend (Via Himachi) Excluding the rediculous mod situation and badly made patch's that i need to patch anyway the game work's it's ok the game is better than the original and to be fair it is abit more playable than the old one.TLDR the game is improved but paid mods make it worse The game is a better standalone game but not by much a good enough upgrade if i was on console but the loss of the mod's support and the fact that mods to legendary edition make it work better than this does the legendary edition would be my personal choice

review: Product received for free. I first played trough this game on Xbox 360 in 2011 and then on PC after buying the Legendary edition (which is why I got the Special Edition for free) and this is a summary of what I think Somewhat updated visuals (including much better anti aliasing method redone textures that is higher resolution than even the official high res texture pack by Beteshda for the original game as well as vastly better lightening and special effects) but no new content. In either case the fact that the game is now 64 bit (and the ability to adress much more memory) makes this a definite improvement over vanilla skyrim especially in terms of the potential for modding regardless of what you think of the visual improvements. The game also seems more stable than the original game so far (about 15 hours in and no crashes or problems spotted).
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I don't really see how you can complain about this. If you don't already own Skyrim now you can get the original plus all the DLC plus an updated 64 bit engine. If you do already own Skyrim plus all the DLC you get this version for free.The only complaint I could think of would be the fact that some of the mods for the original Skyrim will not work until things like SKSE are updated to work with the Special Edition. That will take awhile but for most of the best mods it'll happen.Personally I'll keep playing the original until a few of my "must have" mods have been converted but I'm definitely excited to have this with an updated 64 bit engine.

review: This game is the same as the Original no fixes or aditional quests. A little frustrating that the bugs didnt get fixed that have been glaring since 2011 including the internal timings being linked directly to FPS and refresh rate of monitor and as was mostly expected any modded save games will end up being incompatible from the original over to the SE version.. BUT that said It is an improvment over the original.. graphics aside for most people (myself included) this game will be more stable for you after then engine switch to 64 bit. I find the Graphics aditions to be noticable and enjoyable to have default with no modding needed to look breathtaking and modding it now only improves it further. The modding community isnt QUITE as dedicated to Skyrim SE or at least seems that way with a very slow process or no process in switching mods from original 32 bit skyrim to 64 bit skryimSE ... so unfortunately some of the bigger mods you may have used may not be available .. YET .. most major ones have been switched over and or are in the process of being converted. the primary holdup being the lack of the SKSE 64 bit being done (which is actively being worked on as I type this). Is it esential to make the switch to S? Maybe maybe not.. not yet.. but it shows immense promise. The base game itself will always be great and the modded content will only improve as time goes on to eventually bring it into the standard we were all used to in the Vanilla Skyrim. In time the mods will likely even be bigger and better for SE than the Vanilla one. TLDR It's not a Nirn shattering change from the original however there are enough things to make it worth the upgrade and in time I feel it /will/ have a better platform to work with than the original. Get it if you can next time its on sale and if you already got it for free then try it!

review: Played the hell out of original Skyrim I actually ran out of things to do dungeons stopped resetting everywhere I went I had already plundered. Walked away from it years passed memories faded the dead slumbered...Picked up a Vive recently and I was interested to note that Skyrim was listed under the supported games for Vorpx a driver that makes games playable in VR. I hadn't played Skyrim in awhile it might be a fresh experience I thought.Reinstalled Skyrim to check it out after installing a few choice mods for SE fired up the Vive loaded the Vorpx started Skyrim and... there's several very poignant VR experiences out there like theBlu Batman VR Experience Vanishing Realms games made specifically for VR that give you that sense of "being there" Skyrim SE with the Vorpx Driver might as well be one of those games. When you combine these things you stop merely "playing" Skyrim and you start "Experiencing" it. I feel at one with every rock every reed of every plant every texture of every surface in the game I feel like I can reach out and touch Lydia's face as if she's stading before me ever ready to carry my burdens I feel like I'm standing in the Dragon's flame in the North's cold embrace somewhere on the rooftop of the world miles away from where I am who I am what I am. I look around me now and all I see is Skyrim from its bubbling brooks to its roaring rapids from it's grassy foothills to its frozen mountains the weather on my face the sunshine at my back my enemies driven before me the lamentations of the women all the best things in this... new life.One day you will find my dried and withered husk VR headset strapped to me face I will have assimilated myself into the system and my birth cry will be the ringing of every telephone on earth and any mortal brave enough to acccept the call will hear my Thu'um "Slen Tiid Vo! Motha Fockas!"

review: In short this is most beatiful and smooth "Enhanced edition" I ever see.In long two month ago I bought new videocard (GTX 1060 average modern mediocrity) and tried out original skyrim on Ultras. It looked like *** in comparison to modded graphics so I went all the step core + ENB and was happy When I launched Skyrim SE today I see awful vanilla textures of cart and jarl Ulfric then I saw flying horse in Helgen and then I thought that all this special edition is one big mistake...But when I got out of the cave and see Bleak Falls under realistic sky in a mist with ray of soft light coming everywhere I was overjoyed and understandood that Bethesda made a great work. All skyrim scenery transforms into one smooth and beatiful world and though there are poor textures here and there especially on NPC's faces and hands overall experience is one huge step ahead... simply wondering around returned me 5 years back in time to the same shocking emotion of immersive alive open world which became solid and refined in terms of visuals again.10/10 I highly recommend game as it is now and no amount of bugs or poor textures can spoil that wonderful feeling you got from playing elder scrolls in new light.I am rather sceptical and whiny gamer but here.. it is simply amazing and I guess with proper adaption of mods this game will live more 5 years as an reference game for RPG genre.

review: Product received for free. alright first of all let me say this game is a classic and one many rpg players or gamers in general will never forget me included but does this remaster live up to the hype? yes and noI cant really complain about wasting money because I got it for free alongside the other people with all the DLC i digress what i mean by no is the pc players specifically the modded players. I myself played around 430 hours of always 100+ mods and it was amazing i loved the game skyrim base and with mods the entire experience kicks off but any modded player will tell you skyrim just isnt as good without mods the graphics cant compare some followers e.g. Sofia are far superior and much more. And i completely agree I would never play skyrim vanilla vs skyrim modded if i had the choice. and its just the vanilla vs modded experience is heavily one sided on the mod side so theres no point instantly upgrading unless you yourself are a modder and want to use the new engine to create mods.but what i mean by yes is in about 2 3 months if enbs are supported and the modders of skyrim port their mods into the new game as many are already itll be faaaaaaaaar better because of bethesda fixing some bugs and the new 64bit engine and the scripts (although when it comes out you should 100% swap to skse se because its far far far superior and many mods require it e.g skyui) so when everything gets updated and ported it should be a far superior experience compared to 2011 skyrim.overall i most likely wont be playing the game for a while at least until skse or skyui somehow is supported for the new game. But when those mods are ported and availible for the game? ill be playing like its 2011 again im really excited for the remastered mods but a remaster of the actual game? didnt need it it wouldve been nicer to see a full new fresh remaster of oblivion or morrowind instead. so in conclusion theres no point instantly upgrading unless you yourself are a modder and want to use the new engine to create mods. However if you just want to play the game without mods go ahead and play its just a better skyrim for you but if you want mods youre gonna have to wait until skse se releases but when it does ill be playing it for sure alongside of many other people
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I never modded the graphics while playiing the original so I'm strictly basing this on improvement over vanilla (graphically speaking) original Skyrim.This is a vast improvement over the original for the most part but it still has a ways to go before it's the improvement I expected. I don't know if they're going to be improving them further in the updates but if so I suggest they start with the character models and waterfalls. Some of the leaves look like virtual plastic and the animals could use some updating too.Overall the environment is extremely well done. I found myself looking at everything and forgetting I was going somewhere. Definitely worth the download. If Bethesda doesn't fix the graphical issues the community will. Plus it's a free game if you had the original.Oh it may just be me but all the sound past the Bethesda logo is way too quiet on my headphones. I read they actually downgraded the sound from the original by compressing it all so maybe that's why?

review: Product received for free. I would take most of the performance related reviews with a grain of salt. The framerate for me on ultra settings isnt perfect (40fps but with below recommended pc requirements) but this is to be expected considering the improved graphics ive also yet to experience a single crash. Now as far as the actual improvments go its a signifcant improvment upon the OG skyrim. Lastly the mods while i personally dont use many (especially with the special edition) the utter rage people have regarding mods on the special edition is idiotic. While yes some mods just wont work and others will need to be updated what were people expecting everything to just work all hunky dory? its a new engine for christs sake. If you dont like it play the OG skyrim with the mods that apprently make it look/run better anyway no ones forcing you to buy this. Anyways mods on the special edition should be bigger and better than before thanks to the special edition being 64 bit.So should you buy it? I would but it thats my opinion look at what the game offers and decide if you can justify spending the gold (and if your pc can handle it of course).

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I give the remaster a thumbs up. Why?1. It was free.2. The 64bit upgrade gives us a lot more options where modding is concerned and greater stability.Don't really get the negative reviews as some are saying that it was the same game as before which is what bethesda said it would be with some upgrades in certain areas i.e(lighting water shders etc) . This remaster wasn't supposed to be huge for pc it was meant to be big for the consoles. Which having played skyrim on the console I can see how the improvements listed would be huge for console players.Edit. After having played the game for a few more hours I figured I would give my review a little update.The stability in this game is amazing. I remember having a few texture enhancements and getting open cities of skyrim and going into Whiterun just to see my frames tank as soon as the gates opened (same rig with no upgrades between games) now I can open the gates and my frames dont change from 60. Also many of the texture mods from Skyrim work and more are being added to the nexus and bethesda.net constantly. So I still say that the upgrade in the engine was well worth it.Helpful tip run the game in fullscreen borderless it really seems to help performance wise.To those who were wanting to know.I7 4790k980tiGame on HDD144hz Monitor Locked at 6016gigs of Ram
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Played enough to see that it is just Skyrim with updated graphics. Which is perfectly fine. Now that the game is 64 bit expect much better mod support/ports of mods once SKSE gets updated.Impactful changes Borderless windowed works really well. I can alt tab easily even during loading screens and don't have any cursor glitches in the few times I tried it.Audio quality is a lot worse as they've decided to change the .wav files into .xwm with quite a bit of compression. I'm sure there will be a mod to fix this in the future as it just requires replacing audio files with .wavs or better quality .xwms.If you don't have this for free wait for substantial mod support before buying unless you know you're okay with Vanilla Skyrim.

review: Product received for free. 64 bit engine processing means greater amount of RAM can be implemented into both the game and mods without overly heavy scripting. This is a GOOD THING. If you didn't already own the DLC for the original game which all came out within the first year and a half of a now 5 year old game and you didn't get the free upgrade the only person to blame is yourself. Clearly you didn't enjoy it enough to buy the extended content for it so why should you get that content for free now? This version of the game very quickly replaced my love for vanilla Skyrim with higher frame rates higher default color contrast and 64 bit processing. The trees are actually green now! I love it!For the best mods head over to the Nexus Mods website (just Google it). If you install all your mods manually and have compatibility issues or it kills your game you'll likely have to start from scratch and re install everything. Save yourself the headache and stick with the in game mod downloads (easy) or the Nexus Mod Manager (more control can install mods not on Bethesda's list). NMM is free for download after registering on Nexus Mods's website. If a mod doesn't work just uninstall it through the manager. Super easy!For those new to modding some essential immersive mods to look at (all free) *****Unofficial Skyrim Special Edition Patch (tons of bug fixes constantly being updated A MUST HAVE)***** Achievement Mods Enabler (must be manually installed and Steam restarted enables achievements while using mods) Total Character Makeover (improved faces bodies etc) Alternate Start Live Another Life (replaces the long Skyrim intro with a shorter to the point one) Vivid Weathers (more/better weather variety) Skyrim Flora Overhaul (better trees/foliage) Even Better Quest Objectives Open Cities Skyrim (aka OCS) (major cities now part of overworld map instead of their own loading screen WARNING Not compatible with many texture/mesh mods use in Vanilla SE only) Relationship Dialogue Overhaul (more dialogue among all NPCs) Immersive Citizens AI Overhaul (citizens now run from danger interact more naturally between each other includes compatibility for Open Cities mod) Run For Your Lives &amp When Vampires Attack (citizens will run from dragon and vampire attacks in sities/towns only guards/mercs will fight) Realistic Lighting Overhaul (better shaders/lighting darker shadows/nights so carry a torch with you always) Realistic Ragdolls and Force (no more sliding around as if on ice) Immersive Amazing Follower Tweaks (increased follower limit better follower AI useful follower tools like summon and manage follower outfit)And if you've got the rig for it here's the graphics mods to be looking at ENB (in game graphics/shader manipulation for on the fly changes the base binary needed for most great graphics mods with many mods including specialized ENB support) Re Engaged ReShade and ENB (graphics shaders overhaul w/ support for both vanilla and ENB shaders) Static Mesh Improvement mod (not compatible with OCS) Enhanced Blood Textures SE Book Covers Skyrim (HD textures for most books) Realistic Water Two Nordic Snow SSE Texture Pack Osmodius (replaces almost all Vanilla landscape and city textures with 2K HD textures)And for the dirty perverts who like to play UNP Female Body Renewal (prettier females comes in both SFW and NSFW varieties) Pride of Valhalla (for use with UNP WARNING Huge textures will slow down performance if not installed for what your PC can handle) Dibella's Compulsion (lore friendly nude spell/power) Immersive Wenches (including optional expansions to the base mod)Welcome to the renewed age of SKYRIM!

review: Product received for free. Special Edition brings you back into the Skyrim you know and love but maybe a bit too much like the original. At this time the game still has many of the bugs that Skyrim originally launched with like some collisions issues with items "exploding" upon entering an area and being sent in every direction possible and clipping through doors when entering. Now these for the most part don't ruin the game really at all but the only thing that remains broken in both versions of the game now is Dragonborn. It is still an absolute mess and requires the use of the console just to fix the quests and advance. Now with these grievances aside the game does look quite nice the graphical upgrade is noticeable compared to the vanilla and the lighting effects do make a large difference especially in the southern forests of Falkreath at night. If you did not recieve it for free for owning the collection I would still say it's worth it just because it is still Skyrim but yes overall it is a small upgrade for the price. 8/10.

review: Product received for free. I start playing...And it looks like Skyrim. I mean JUST like Skyrim. Maybe there's some more fog? I dunno.Now I will give credit where credit is due There were some parts as I explored from an old savegame that DID look different. The character models are noticeably smoother. The fire looks cooler. There's a couple nice lighting effects.But by and large it looks the same as the Ordinary Edition.Downsides I noticed a lot of rings running through everything as I ran around which was not particularly immersive. As I ran through the wilderness in some places I noted that the extra grass shrubs little rocks etc. didn't appear until I got close to them and from a distance everything was flat unlike Ordinary Edition without mods. This was also not particularly immersive. Everything seemed to take a long time to load. Overall performance seemed notably worse even on rather low graphics settings at least when I was in outdoor areas there was a fair amount of general slowness and lag.May or may not be downsides First person view is a bit closer to the ground I think and everything is definitely "zoomed in" close up things are REALLY close and you can't see as much of your hands/weapons. This might be confusing to longtime players of the original. Also apparently you now need to have an account with Bethesda in order to use mods. And the main menu doesn't have a link to the options menu which is just dumb IMO but that's a minor point.In summary Updated graphics in some areas that are not that special is the only upside that I noticed. Performance was worse than vanilla Ordinary Edition and I'd say slightly worse than heavily modded Ordinary Edition as well though that varies depending on how much save bloat you have. I did not pay anything for this game and I'm glad I didn't. If you already have Skyrim don't waste your money on this. If you don't well both are about the same price so pick whichever you want. If you don't care that much about graphics I recommend you skip this version.

review: Product received for free. I spent over 1 000 hours playing the original on Steam and thousands more hours on Xbox 360. It was my first Elder Scrolls game and after playing all of them from Arena to Oblivion it's still my favorite and the one game I always come back to after I tire of others.The Special Edition does not dissapoint either. It seems a bit underwhelming to some veteran players because the most noticible new feature the improved graphics have been available through mods for a long time. What I think is much more important is the improved stability. After 20 30 hours into a game the original Skyrim would start suffering all sorts of weird glitches and crashes and mods would often bring that on much sooner. Then there was the constant crashing from running out of RAM an other limitations of the original 32 bit build.Special Edition fixes this and while I'm still waiting for my favorite mods to update a lot of really great content has already been updated or made newly for the Special Edition.Disclaimer I did receive this game for free because I already owned Legendary Edition. If it had not been free I probably would be more critical of the lack of new content and the new mechanism that disables acheivements if you're using mods.

review: Product received for free. Same game just re textured and graphically improved. Not much of a difference tbh and having this game compared to the older game doesn't really make a difference to PC players because we could probably make the original look better than this with mods. I just think remastering it was a good business decision for Bethesda because of the current generation console players (PS4 + XBONE). Allowing them to play such a good game is a great decision and it could also entice those who had Skyrim on last gen who have then upgraded to buy it again and play it. If you're on PC and you didn't get it for free like most did I wouldn't buy it.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Heya All I am very happy for this update. I have played with Vanilla Skyrim SE and like what I see so far. However I am tabling it for now until some mods I like get converted. I beat skyrim on an un modded playthru during origional release. So I got that feel already. These days I prefer the modded experiance for some aspects of my play thru.SE Pros Updated Base World Graphics Asthetics and ENB (lighting). Seems to be nicer and more true to Bethesda fantasy but with better graphics. So possibly may not need as many visual mods. Played for a short while looked at many world textures and I personally am happy. Engine Converted to 64 Bit allowing game and some mods to function better on current PCs. This paves the way for potentially new mods that can do much more than before. Thats up to the creativeness of the community though.SE Cons "Unofficial Skyrim Patch" was not integrated into the base game to my knowledge. I do not know if Bethesda performed any offical bug fixes to the base game or not. But my hunch is we will still need the "Unofficial Skyrim Patch" to fix alot of things in the world. Some players have tried the patch on Skyrim SE but it seems to cause problems. So we need to wait for the mod to be updated to work better with Skyrim SE. Old textures on Armors weapons equipment house hold objects dungeon objects and thousands of other items don't look updated to me. Looking forward to the Static Mesh improvement mod HD weapon/Armor mods to be converted to Skyrim SE. Not looking for non skyrim items/equipment meshes. Just would like higher quality meshes for existing skyrim equipment. Kinda the bridge between lore friendly and better looking. Not older PC friendly. If you ran Skyrim on High/Ultra 5 6 years ago you might be at low/Medium settings today with Skyrim SE. If you've updated your computer since then like I did. You might still be at High/Ultra. No NPC or Character mesh/skin updates. Still have origional character looks/feels. Will need modding to touch up some people. Waiting for CBBE to be converted... Don't judge me... &gt .&gt Many older Mods may never work again unless the Mod Author comes back to update it or another mod author takes over the project and tries to update it.Other Notes PC Performance. Some users are reporting sinificant performance issues with their computers. When they list their system specs and I compare it to mine sometimes we're fairly similar. Yet I am not noticing any visual or perfomance issues. My rig is a Win 10 PRO i7 6700k 32GB ram GeForce GTX 970 and Samsung Evo 850 SSDs. Some users are reporting Bugs with the starting scene on the cart. No mods yet the cart still flips the fraq out or the Horses get in the way during the execution scene. Hopefully a bugfix will come for that soon. Mod Development will take time folks. Its up to you to decide if you want to play a limited mod experiance or wait for a while. thank you all and I hope you enjoy the updates and updated mods. Good luck Mod Makers. Im rooting for you.

And the port to the new engine just makes it more beautiful and immersive. Take it as you will. It's literally the SAME game with the SAME content as The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim released in 2011. It just looks better and that is what they were marketing about it. Personally I really like that Bethesda did this and I honestly hope they do this with Morrowind and maybe even Oblivion.And before I forget YOU GOT THIS FOR FREE YOU IDIOTS SO SHUT UP. They could of said "Umm so yeah we are gonna release Skyrim again but with a different engine and it will look nicer. And you know what? We are gonna make you pay 40 even thought you already own the exact same game." They could of. But they didn't. This isn't EA.Edit Grammer

review: Product received for free. Seeing so many people spitting venom at this special edition I'm a little dumbfounded.Why do they hate it so much Mods are now incompatible Bugs are still there Saves incompatibility because of mods Bethesda wants moneyWell first of all that's true mods played a hell of a lot in the popularity of Skyrim. They're awesome and indispensable. Without them Skyrim would never be the same. And now they're all broken in this special edition.But they're currently being modified to be compatible it's only been launched 3 days ago and a lot of those awesome mods are already available... So we can expect before long if not all but at least a big majority of the most popular ones to arrive on this version.Then Skyrim was always bugged as hell and this version is not an exception from what people say. However we can expect updates and bug fixes. On this point I have yet to play it enough to talk more about it.Another point was that saves which use mods might be incompatible and that's a shame. But on another hand you can't really expect anyone to give you a warranty on something completely different from what they provided you. And about Bethesda wanting more money. Well as most people on PC we received it for FREE because we loved the game and that's why we bought the 3 DLCs (even though I don't really consider Heartfire as a real DLC). Not only that it's a completely separate installation so if you want to keep your skyrim modded like crazy with your old characters you can play with them without any kind of problem or conflict. And the saves are also separated you only have to copy/paste them to play with your characters on the special edition (at least if you deactivated your mods and saved before). So why would you complain ? And also this special edition is a great way for those who never played this title to start. And I still believe 40e for getting everything is really not a lot for what this game has to offer on the opposite of several other titles where the price never went down with the time the price of skyrim was always reduced to the point of having it at 15e without sales.Now about what they added well mainly they improved the performances. Comparison just came out and the special edition performs better them the old one on the same configuration without mods. Hence you can expect to be able to mod this version more heavily before having performance issues. And that's something I'm waiting for. They also improved the graphics in comparison to the base game and I have to say from the little bit I played it does look good. I was never fan of big ENBs and prefered using IMAGINATOR so it's what I like to play. However for those who like to play with ENBs one of Fallout 4 is already available on the nexus and we can expect a lot more in the coming days. And for those who nerver played this game or don't like using mods it's a really good improvement.In conclusion I do believe this special edition is a good thing. It will help us mod skyrim to a new level and also adds some pretty nice features in addition.PS for those who use laptops if you're encountering stutters you might want to check if you launched the game with your chipset and not with your graphic card and if that's the case force the card to be used. Happened to me and took me a while to realise where it came from.

review: As a person who doesn't like grinding games this was a great buy. It's a (mostly) quick level RPG where at least one major development will happen every few hours of play time. It also has enough questing to keep you interested for quite some time especially as you won't be able to complete every quest in a single game. Difficulty settings too fun!And as a person who likes freedom of choice also a great buy. Make money legitimately by selling weapons you made. Help the man get his golden heirloom back. Break into houses lockpick the chests without being caught and sell the stuff on the black market. Go on a mission to kill a building full of civilians to satisfy a civil dispute at high pay.It's quite fun to play without looking things up on the internet. Without looking anything up I still wouldn't know the true depth of the game.This falls into the "Games I always hear about but never investigated regret not buying sooner" category. I can't put it down.

review: Leave it to Bethesda to bring back a remastered classic that doesn't run.When I open this game it renders my pc inoperable no alt+tabbing out no ctrl+alt+del no alt+F4 just a black screen with the Skyrim theme song mocking me. I have to hard restart my system because there's no getting out of it.Being an optimist I tried this three times in a row. I am now a pessimist.Oh and if you're thinking "Well maybe your system just can't handle the remastered version " take a look at my profile for my tower specs.I guess I'll just keep playing the modded original...EDIT The game now works thanks to a graphics driver update. HOWEVER it has crashed 3 times during 4 hours of gameplay not to mention the game looks worse than my slightly modded original. Granted this release was meant for consoles so I'm not even really sure why they did a horrible PC port. The game still has all the original glitches and painful inconveniences that the original has and the PC community already had unlocked resolution and framerate with way better mods years ago. So yeah I don't recommend getting this for PC.

review: Product received for free. Right off the bat If you never really played Skyrim before buy this one. This is your chance to experience the vanilla game at its best. That being said though it is the vanilla game no mods from the last version will work on it. I have full faith however that pretty soon (once SKSE and SkyUI come out) all the mods really worth downloading will be on the Skyrim SE Nexus. Now if you've played the game before I would still buy it but not at full retail. Wait for a sale by then alot of mods will be out. What alot of people forget to point out is that not only is Skyrim SE a graphical improvement but it is also 64 bit meaning mods will be able to do bigger and better things with upgraded software and more RAM to work with. The game will be more stable and crash less even if you have mods galore. Very soon I think this game will be significantly better than the 32 bit version considering the move to 64 bit architecture. Once mods like SKSE and SkyUI come out which I predict will be in the next month Skyrim SE will have as big of a modders community as the original.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Honestly a serious let down The difference between this and regular skyrim edition is that this version uses a very basic ENB setting it has Skyrim Flora overhaul lite lite version and i think a 2k texture mod instead of standard..The interface for addons in game is an improvement but in the long run there's way to many mods missing atm for it to be valuable. Also.On to the largest Issue I had with this...&gt &gt &gt Spoilers Below this &lt &lt &lt No Mods installed just booted up on ultra settings and starting a new game.The usual Cart you start on not sure if it happened to anyone else but mine did a 360 flyby of the world just shortly before arriving into Helgen. After that conundrum I got off my trusted cart and was greeted by a Horse that was stuck out of place idling in front of me. Legit a horse staring me in the face! Not to mention that the horse took up Hadvars spot so Hadvar kept circling the horse while reading his standard script dialog. After finishing creating my character the game runs nicely forward no big issue here some smaller AI screwups that normally happen when they get stuck on different objects here and there.After entering the Helgen Keep with Ralof and going into the Torture chamber there's the option to lockpick a cell to find a corpse and some items. Upon opening this cage the corpse proceeded to ragdoll the out of the cage flying about like a madman before settling down halfway through the wall.. After this incident it was pretty much smooth sailings until I arrived at the large room just before the drawbridge to the end cave.Here 1 of the archers decided gravity was not his deal and flew up halfway into the ceiling and proceeded to suffocate and die. after clearing the room he was still stuck up there in the ceiling.Moving forward into the area with the drawbridge Ralof goes up and pulls the lever afterwards he starts levitating up into the ceiling and flies over the drawbridge area into the cave area bouncing up and down slightly along the way.Confunded by this behaviour as I follow him into the cave when I take my first step on the drawbridge I am forcepushed forward about halfway over the bridge getting confused I back up towards the Keep dungeon again but I am met with an invisible wall and the bridge decides to become liquid form and I just fall through it.After this it was pretty normal up until the bear part which as the true basterd I am decide to sneak shoot him with my newly recieved long bow the Bear decides standing isn't enough but he flies up into the air a few meters and floats towards me with a savage roar... Screaming in fear of flying bears I run around like a crazy person shooting all my arrows into it hoping to kill it but it seems the hitbox of the bear was left on the ground because Ralof starts hitting the air and eventually the bear dies...At this point I'm very confused how this actually got released.. and after getting out of the cave I save and exit vowing to never try to best flying evil bears again.Hope you found it helpful.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Great new graphics! Love the new lighting.If your FPS drops it's because the game defaults to integrated graphics. To fix this you need to manually add it on the NVIDIA control panel.Right click on your desktopOpen NVIDIA control panelClick Manage 3D settingsGo to the Program Settings tabClick AddClick browse and go to your Skyrim special edition directoryClick on SkyrimSE.exeClick add selected programChange the preferred graphics processor to your cardClick apply

review: Product received for free. i7 6700HQ with 2.60ghz and 16gb of ram plus a gtx970 and i run on low with 7fps wtf? any help here?edit now all i get is a black screen and sound and the only way to close the game is to restart my pcedit got the game to run but im still getting 7fps and now there are gray spots all over the npcslast edit i got the game to work now after doing all thisRight click on your desktop and select NVIDIA Control Panel.In the Control Panel select Manage 3D settings then click on the Program Settings tab. Next to the "Select a program to customize" option click the Add button. From the pop up window navigate to the folder where the game is installed.Select the executable file for Skyrim Special Edition.In the "Select the preferred graphics processor for this program" option open the drop down menu and select High performance NVIDIA processor and confirm.To improve performance go to the "Specify the settings for this program " section click Power management mode and select Prefer maximum performance and confirm.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Before we start I got this game for FREE. Think of it what you want but this may be somewhat of a biased review judging by the fact that I got this game for no cost but I will try to keep it as balanced as possible and address the views as if I was someone purchasing it. For free this game is a great add on to the original game. You get better looking graphics better looking trees better water and an amazing depth of field option. However the dissapointing factor is that some of the major bugs of the old Skyrim haven't been fixed such as the buggy physics that occur when you run the game at anything over 60 frames. You would hope that Bethesda would fix these issues that hundreds of mods were made to fix instead of focusing corely on the graphic enhancement but sadly that isn't the case. All in all the Special Edition removes the need for many ENB's and High Texture Pack mods but many of the bugs still aren't fixed. If you are able to get it for free through owning the old Skyrim as well as all of the DLC's then I would definitely recommend downloading it. If you are a new player to skyrim looking to buy this game I would wait and see what they do with it. I am giving this game a thumbs up because in my perspective I enjoy because it's free but there are still issues with it at release.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. If you're not one for dedicating mods into skyrim on the pc plateform for HEAVY graphical improvements then this is worth getting the rest of the dlc imo to get this free version. However if that deal is over i would strongly recomend just buying the original and mod it anyway. It can become a passion but thats not for everyone and i understand that. Personally I prefer the overall look of skyrim special edition over the current mods plus the fact that it is MUCH more stable even without mods. No crashes so far it has God Rays which no modder has made yet which is a nice touch and everything runs smoothly together. If you only need another dlc to finish off the deal i reccomend it. Especially if your not into heavy modding.

review: Product received for free. A great remaster for an already great game getting mods for this game could not have gotten any easier as you can now install them from the game (though it was already quite easy using nexus mod manager). The graphics are great overall though you can achieve higher using ohter mods (currently not available in the special edition). I played skyrim when it originally came out and it is refreshing to replay it again it doesnt feel old at all. Alduin looks amazing as well as guilds such as the dark brotherhood thieves guild and the companions in whiterun. I highly reccomend downloading the unnofical patch notes from the mod menu in the main menu of the game they work perfectly and does not require you to wait for the develepors to fix. I am quite dissapointed they didnt add and extra quests or DLC but that is exactly why they are allowing you to easily the install the mods. Although the arent out yet i highly suggest you download the following mods FalskaarUnnoficial patch notes (is currently available)the grey cowl of nocturnal (i believe it is called) Legacy of the DragonbornOverall a great experience from the time i played i can easily see myself playing 60+ hours. Although i feel quite dissapointed we didnt get a new Elder Scrolls i feel that this suffices and allows me to immerse myself into the lore of skyrim and tamriel using the main game and the various different mods.i use a gtx 750 ti and an i5 processor and im able to run the special edition at 50 60 fps .great game for the price regardless if its your first time or revisiting skyrim after a few years (or 6 7 months like myself)

review: Product received for free. There are some things about this that are really well done for the update. The lighting is fascinating the extra weather effects like fog/haze/blowing snow is really nice. It added a new depth to the visual aspect of the game. The depth of field blurring has been interesting as well.Pleased that an update has FINALLY fixed the alt+tab issue so you can minimize your game pretty worry free now which is nice.My biggest thumbs down for the remastered game is that they didn't really do much to enhance the ground environment. The trees and plants (not all) still have a very...choppy and 2 D feel to the foliage/flowers which I was hoping would've changed. Still some silly glitchy things like NPCs standing inside of solid stone structures but that kind of stuff is laughable and doesn't ruin anything.If you have the option to get this for free do it. It's not a disappointment in that aspect. Not sure I'd really be tossing out so much money for basically a giant texture overhaul though. From what I've gathered mods for the original version can do an even better job (I play un modded)...UNLESS you've never played any of the DLC which is included in this version. The extra bits do make for a fun and interesting edition to the game.

review: Product received for free. First of all everyone who gave this a negative review knows absolutely nothing about modding or what this this release will actually do for this game.It is sad to see that this has a "mixed" review pool on Steam already. I don't usually give a about reviews but I didn't expect you people to shut down this. Not because I love skyrim but because this is literally the best thing that could possibly happen to this game and I'll explain why below First of all this game looks AMAZING for a base version. There are so many people in here on it because (read this in Cartman's voice) "I already have a modded version and it looks like this already. This is so stupid blah blah". Let me explain to those of you idiots that gave this a bad review on the first day you exactly what Skryim Special Edition does for the modding community and what this game will become in the next 3 months if not sooner.Skyrim Special Editions main focus was not to put in a few new bushes give the game a new shine and greater viewing distance. That's a bonus. What they actually did here was repackage the game so that it can be executed in 64 bit. They also unlocked and fixed the RAM capabilities. What this means for those of you that don't understand is that this game is now so much easier to mod so much easier to work with and so much more optimized for the future. SO in retrospect all of those beautiful mods that you've seen for the original Skyrim that WILL be redone in due time will be TWICE if not TRIPLE as beautiful and nearly LIMITLESS in capability.. I can't stress enough how important this is. We're basically starting a whole new generation of mods for arguably the most modable game of all time and with it comes a staggering amount of possiblity..So don't just load up the game see that it's the same thing with a few new shiny upgrades and on bethesda and future players that actually read reviews by giving it a bad review. You must understand that they were not just releasing this to make you think the ing trees are prettier. Why do you think they gave it away?? It was to plant the seed of the Skyrim Craze all over again. And trust me this is about to get un ing real.10/10 would rant again

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Finally! Here it is. The "new" Skyrim. First off i would like to mention that I played Skyrim on the PS3 since 11 11 11. After a few years I got an old quad core pc and put a gtx660 in it I started with the Legendary Edition of Skyrim. It worked fine. HD Textures a few mods and I had an easy 60fps on ultra. Nowadays I have an i5 6600k gtx 960 4gb and 16gb ddr4 ram. I could not wait for this game so I got scared when i read the first few reviews. Starting the game it choose ultra settings. After the intro chapter i immediatly started wandering Skyrim. Outside in 3rd person mode and running around with a low sun i have between the 35 45 fps. So i wonder wich graphic card the other users use. Recommended is a 780 and with a quick look it looks like it is better than my 960. Anywho inside a dungeon or building it hits a steady 60fps. So please tell us wich gpu you are using just to know a bit better where the bottleneck lies. For the game itself (i just played for 1 hour now) i could say it is not a big difference. Just like other reviews the lightning effects the water effects and some bloom and flowers are nicer than vanilla. But if you walk past a nice piece of stone shining in the darkest dungeon you will see that the textures arent that nice. I could say they didnt even put the HD texture pack from the original in this game. (please correct me if i'm wrong) The quests are the same well the whole game is the same for that matter. Even the strange things like sneaking trough a dungeon spotting an enemy ready your bow and when you shoot the arrow the enemy moves almost a meter to the side without moving a muscle. I mean come on if this is the level of this "special edition" or whatever you like to call it its a shame. Just putting some mods togheter with a 5 year old game isn't doing anything nowadays. I am sure there are a lot more bugs or glitches in the game. They where in the original and if I see after an hour that there are still a few bugs then i believe all of them are still in the game. So maybe just maybe you should buy the original instead of this special edition. Don't forget after the announcement of the special edition all the other skyrim editions rise in price. If you don't like to mess with mods or whatever buy this game...in the sale... For the 10 euro more then the original you could better buy this version. And from now each evening I will pray to the Nine Divines that the Moddcloaks will rise up and modd this game just like the original version. I hope if i dont get lost in Skyrim i update my review. But for now i will recommend this game. Just because it is in my top 5 of best games ever. And hopefully yours too. PS bethesda THANK YOU! for this free game! I really appreciate it. But please come with some updates for the people who cannot play this game like they should with there specs. And please don't be a little tiny bit lazy next time and fix some bugs and some animations from the characters. it brings me back for like 4 years or something.But still try this.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Okay first of all I'm sick of hearing all this whining just because your potato that you have updated your drivers on in 10 years won't run the game at 144fps doesn't mean you have to on the game. First of all I'd like to say this game is way more stable and better looking then the original skyrim and it was nice to recieve this for free as a long time skyrim fan. What's new you may ask? I'd like to address that this game is not a remaster so the content does not change but what does change are the graphics. The graphics are way more smoothed out and are higher quality textures then what they used to be the lighting and godray effects are awesome and make this game outstanding from what it used to be. There's people whining about how they compressed audio files which they did but the characters in the games sound exactly the same this also goes to the music and other sounds. The cons of this game are being so stretched out it's not funny. The greatest thing about this game is they converted Skyrim to 64 bit which means the game is not going to crash if you have half the mods on the Nexus installed and it also means the game won't suffer from too many items in one room moving. It basically increases the amount of RAM your game takes in. I will say something I don't like is the bethesda mod support replacing the Workshop but honestly they almost follow the exact same rules so it's not a huge problem.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition
