review: I can sum up what's wrong with this game in one sentence so bear with me as I explain that sentence. "There is no native Linux client" A significant number of developers publishers and gamers read a sentence like that and simply dismiss it out of hand for a variety of reasons with none of those reasons being valid. The point of developing a Linux client for any game or any software package is not for fiscal return in sales nor just for community goodwill. It isn't to showcase technical prowess or to grow a new market. Not is it just to hush up a very vocal stastical minority of players.The point of developing for Linux is that it enforces Good Coding Practices. Applications that are cross developed for Linux and Windows sets a number of high barriers a developer must address. One of those barriers is code documetation. With multiple operating systems in play code must be well documented so that anybody else reading the code later will know what the original developer intended.Developing with cross platform targets in mind from the start also forces the developer to avoid Operating System specific functions. Developers also have an incentive to avoid Operating System specific API's. Native cross platform development also makes it more likely that the developer will leverage more robust development tools check more of the code for errors before compiling get more detailed reports afterwards on what broke during compiling and ultimately produce cleaner code as a result. Native cross platform development forces developers especially game developers to actually test their shader code on a variety of different hardware types. Supporting AMD alone for example could mean making sure OpenGL and Vulkan shader code runs under as many as 4 different drivers. The more physical graphics cards a developer tests against in house and the more drivers against which those graphics cards are tested make it far more likely that bad or error'd code will be noticed and can be corrected. The sheer scale scope and ambition that Bethesda puts into their games is only matched by what appears to be the sheer scale and scope of Bethesda's apathic coding practices. Bethesda games are legendary for massive bugs glitches and any number of wide ranging issues that would normally spell death for any other developer. From what I've experienced players love Bethesda games because there's something to those games that is more compelling than the broken clients used to play those games.For years players have begged Bethesda to open up their game clients under Open Source licenses. For years players have begged Bethesda to let the players fix those game clients at the code level not at some downloadable mod level. For years Bethesda has responded with a flat "No" I harbor no doubt that if Bethesda had released the Fallout 4 engine under an Open Source license and let the player base bring Skyrim into that engine then there would have been something special. There wouldn't have been sound files that were compressed using some well let's just leave it at noting that the sound is not compressed using a format from Xiph. There wouldn't have been texture packs that were left untouched. There wouldn't have been broken shader codes. If anything it's likely that the extremely talented player base would have ported the graphics code into Vulkan.When I saw Skyrim Special Edition land with no native Linux client as a Zero Day Launch I knew without even checking anything else or even loading the game up that Bethesda hadn't followed coding practices. I knew just from the lack of a product that the code probably had not been tested on a wide range of hardware or driver sets. I knew that Bethesda probably hadn't used platform agnostic development tools and likely had a wide range of Operating System workarounds black boxes and kludges in the ported game. Other developers might want to take notes. Supporting Linux platforms during the product development process as a cross compile with Windows isn't just to make the fan base feel good. It's a very practical and very effective method at making sure that when the product launches... it's a product that works. Not one that locks up and does nothing for hours on end.

review: The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim Special Edition is a remastered version of the popular open world RPG by Bethesda Game Studios.The Empire of Tamriel is on the edge. The High King of Skyrim has been murdered. Alliances form as claims to the throne are made. In the midst of this conflict a far more dangerous ancient evil is awakened. Dragons long lost to the passages of the Elder Scrolls have returned to Tamriel. The future of Skyrim even the Empire itself hangs in the balance as they wait for the prophesized Dragonborn to come a hero born with the power of The Voice and the only one who can stand amongst the dragons.

review: Product received for free. It would be nice if the game would actually recognize that my laptop has a GTX 960m card in it and not force me to use the Intel graphics chipset. Looks like I'll be sticking with the original release but hey at least this was free. I can see why now.UPDATE 1 After spending some time in the NVIDIA Control Panel and setting it to force the GTX960M performance has improved greatly. It's getting there but I'll have to wait until it gets official NVIDIA support before I change my opinion on the game. On another bright side the load times are much faster.UPDATE 2 Performance is much better since doing the switch. While I normally will play at 1080p Medium settings (which results in between 45 and 60fps ) playing on Ultra sets it between 30 and 40.UPDATE 3 Can now play at 900p Ultra with a more than adequate frame rate. My overall experience has been much better since. As a result I'm changing my recommendation to a yes.This is the system I'm using Intel Core i7 6700HQ16 GB RAMNVIDIA GeForce GTX 960M2 TB internal hard drive

review: Product received for free. Really don't see the problems people have with this There's a lot of improved stuff in this game (except the bugs but I'm talking about the engine. For the people crying about mod support it'll always take a while and this version will be a LOT better than the original 32 bit Skyrim. One of the main reasons why this version is a lot better already is cause of the variable FPS. youre not forced to play at 60fps all the time like you did before really good for people with high refreshrate monitors. I'm pretty sure a lot of people will disagree with me but I'm just stating facts. If you have problems with the bad textures just mod them right now Bethesda has confirmed that all old texture and mesh mods are working with this version.Pros64bit / DX11 surely a lot better for mods than 32bit and DX9Unlocked FPS just think about the physics that glitched heavily in 32 bit when uncapping the FPS with the config file.Few environmental additions and improved lighting.ConsExactly the same game without any bug fixes at all. There obviously won't be any new content though.The last time I played Skyrim was on it's release on the Xbox 360 and it's really refreshing to play the somewhat remaster. I remember grinding it heavily back then and I guess I'll do it again. I don't really mind the bugs as im quicksaving in every moment possible just to not get ed over.

review: Product received for free. Do you like Skyrim or have you always wanted to try Skyrim and have been waiting for the perfect edition? Well this is the one to get.It looks better plays better and works better than the previous edition. Mod support is baked into the game so you can load mods in a manner similar to the way they do it in Fallout 4. There's an actual Mod menu in the game and getting mods is as easy as scrolling around picking the mods you want and clicking a button. You don't have to dink around with the Nexus and manual installation nor do you even need to worry about the Workshop on Steam. It's really very nice to just load and go. The Vanilla version of the game without mods looks fantastic. I'd say it's comparable to the previous edition with some heavy graphics mods but the bonus here is that this doesn't compromise your PC as much. The Special Edition is designed to take advantage of Windows 10 and manage memory a lot better. If you're on a 64 bit system with a bunch of RAM you'll finally get to use it. The end result? A gorgeous game that doesn't crash because of memory holes or other weird issues. There's nothing new here in terms of content. It's the full package of Skyrim with all DLC but they didn't add any new areas or quests. The towns and villages all look fantastic with new plants and improved textures but there are no new secrets to unlock. The landscape is covered with more grass more flowers more plants thicker trees and really excellent lighting and shadows but you won't find any new caves or castles. This is just the ultimate version of a game you've probably already played for hundreds of hours. That said Skyrim really is another life and a way to just wander around in a new world for hours on end and this is the most immersive gorgeous way to do it without going through the technical tweaking of old style modding. Yes you can get more mods (at the time of this writing) for the previous edition and do a lot more graphics wise with those mods but they are harder to install and each one takes a toll on the game's performance and might potentially lead to frequent crashes. If you want to skip all that the Special Edition is a great compromise. While the PC version of Skyrim Special Edition won't be as much of a surprise in terms of graphical improvements as compared to the console versions (which are vast improvements over the last gen hardware's graphical capabilities) it's still the most simple way to get into Skyrim with the best possible graphics and most stable engine on a modern PC. Future mods will no doubt make the game even more attractive and now those mods can take advantage of the memory and power available to them. I dig it. I mean it was free anyway so what's not to like? You should definitely download this one though whether you're a new player or an old hand.

review: ((FOR A MORE IN DEPTH REVIEW OF THE GAME ITSELF REFER TO MY VANILLA SKYRIM REVIEW))Special Edition is a great package. Now that the price has been lowered from its original 60 dollar price I can for sure say it is worth it to grab this game if you didn't get it for free for having the Legendary Edition of Skyrim.As far as modding go the in game mod loader is pretty decent. If you play Fallout 4 its essentially the same format. Also locks achievements however which is easily mendable with a couple added files. The modding community for this version suffers due to the lack of SKSE support. There is no foreseeable release date for the 64 bit version of skyrim script extender and thats a fairly large issue for people that relied on a couple big name mods in the previous version (SkyUI to name one.)Aside from that the game runs great and was well optimized. If you never got the opportunity to play Skyrim I recommend buying this.

review: 10 / 10Dec. 17 2016Skyrim is the best game of it's type. Skyrim S E is Skyrim with an upgraded 64 bit game engine which makes it more stable for modding. Skyrim S E works with my game saves from the original Skyrim. Just copy and paste the files from the one save games folder into the other. You don't have to restart the game from the beginning. Also on Steam this game can use Steam Cloud to backup your game saves in case your hard drive crashes.Skyrim is the best game of it's type. It is a first person (and/or third person) adventure game set in a medieval fantasy world with magic dragon's elves and other mythical creatures. This game has a story line based on games of the Elder Scrolls series Morrowwind Oblivion and Skyrim.. However you are not stuck to the story line were you move from one battle to the next with some story line to tie them together. You can wander around on it's open world / sandbox map choosing which quests to do and when. If you can't win a boss battle you can do other things then come back when you are tuffer.Not only is it a stable high end game 10/10 in it's standard ( vanilla/ un modded ) version. but there are 1000's of mods you can add to the game to change almost anything you can think of. This makes the Elder Scrolls and Fallout series twice as good. Below is the Nexus website link were you can get game mods the tools to install them and make your own mods. The Nexus website has 10 000's of mods and tools for a long list of games. The mods are all FREE and are made by other gamer's who make mods mostly for the love of their favorite games. Some of the modder's are professional's in the game development industry. This is were I go for game mods. It's like free shopping. They even have virtual gun's and tropical fruit.http //www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/searchresults/?Also Bethesda Games has their own mod downloader and installer for those who want to use mods the quick and easy way. Below is a link to their webpage In the upper right corner of the webpage click on were is say's Launcher. This will give you an installer for Bethesda's own mod installer and game launcher. This will give you access to the new Creation Kit's for Fallout 4 and Skyrim S E.https //mods.bethesda.net/#en/workshop/skyrim

review: Product received for free. WHAT TO EXPECT A significant visual upgrade to the base game. Less performance restrictions thanks to running at 64bit with DirectX 11 Better Audio QualityWHAT NOT TO EXPECT Visuals and texture resolution surpassing extensive base game modding New content Better menus and UI Your old mods to work Your old modded save files to work proper 144hz support 21 9 support and/or 4k support (potentially possible with tweaks but feedback suggests it's not stable or optimized well.)CURRENT REVIEWSIt's currently sat at "Mixed". That could change but I'll address the reviews I have seen and shed some light on the overall balance.POSITIVE REVIEWS People who avoided performance issues Bethesda fanbois People who accurately knew what to expect People who just like Skyrim I guessNEGATIVE REVIEWS People who didn't avoid performance issues Anti Bethesda hecklers People who succumbed to hype and are disappointed People who just hate Skyrim I guessABOUT THE PRICESkyrim Special Edition is 30 $40 35 or whatever currency of your country. It's expensive. It's just shy of being a full priced game. I don't necessarily agree with this but I accept it because of the reasons mentioned below.I am putting my review up recommending skyrim special edition because Skyrim and it's DLC has been on sale for almost no money multiple times for years. Even as part of the marketing campaign for the Special Edition Skyrim and it's DLC was put on sale so that people who were missing certain DLC or wanted a cheaper upgrade could get that upgrade at a significant discount. I feel the effort made by Bethesda to accommodate PC players leading up to this release cancels out the vocal minority who missed news and updates about the arrangement and are now complaining about the price on PC.Also a side note about the console versions. I feel like the console version is reasonably priced. Modded Skyrim for PC is one thing but to bring Skyrim back on consoles with impressive visual upgrades and mod support is huge. It looked average compared to PC on the PS3 and 360.The effort was made for PC players to get this upgrade for free or at a discount because to us it's not really much of an upgrade. Some people didn't get around to preparing for the upgrade and will now bitterly have to cash out full price if they wanna play now or wait for it to go on sale. Either way .
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Everything is finally looking good! No crashes and running stably at 144fps on my 1070. This is still the original Skyrim + DLCs but it looks and feels much better. Highly recommend if you were a fan of the original version like me. PREVIOUS REVIEWSPlayed through the opening scene early today and experienced some serious issues. No full on crashes but I was experiencing some nasty FPS drops down to 7 8 from 110 for seemingly no reason. It happened specifically when the dragon comes down when you're about to get beheaded and while you're making your escape during character creation and in the catacombs. I was able to kind of hack my way around this by Shift+Tab opening the Steam Overlay briefly and that would bring the frames back up for a little bit.Skyrim is one of my favorite games ever and I will 100% play this but I'd wait to buy if you haven't until Bethesda can fix this and the other issues being reported.Update November 18 2016The framerate bug still exists bug crashes seem to have gone away for the most part. I've moved to the beta patches and would recommend those for everyone experiencing similar issues to me. Also I have found a workaround for the framerate drops. Go into your Nvidia Control Panel and under 3D Settings &gt Manage 3D Settings Program Settings &gt Sykrim Special Edition (full path of executable) Change "Monitor Technology" from "Use global settings" to "Fixed Refresh". You'll be capped at 60fps but it makes the game playable.Update November 24 2016Haven't been able to get a consistent 144fps for some reason but I think it may be due to the game not picking up the display adapter settings for whatever reason.

review: This is coming from someone who already has 700 hours in TES Skyrim Legendary Edition (LE).Skyrim Special Edition is basically Skyrim with all the DLC's wrapped into one package and a graphics update from what I can tell. How can I tell that the graphics are updated? When I had the LE of Skyrim I usually played with mods that increased UI elements as well as certain aspects of the textures like blood. Now the graphics update that I am referring to is that the worlds seems to be more alive than it was in previous editions of Skyrim. Another plus is that from what I've read the graphics engine has been updated to use DX11 and from my experience it runs very smooth now compared to the older versions. Pros +All DLC s available as well as the High Resolution DLC. +DX11+Defacto modding version now+Updated graphics+All the pluses of Skyrim are combined into this as well. +From what I ve experienced the load times are much faster however this could be because the game is now on my SSD.+From what I've experienced the game is much more stable than the old Skyrim was.Cons No Steam Workshop integration yet Some bugs remain Duel casting bound weapons are still automatically set to the left hand Dragon fights are still bland

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: So... yeah. Skyrim Remastered is basically the same game as the original version launched in 2011 but with some nifty new graphical effects and the DLC already bundled in. Textures actually seem to be... average at best but mods should correct that in time.The new graphical effects could be achieved on the original game by using mods but their quality varied and performance tended to tank depending on what you were you using. A powerful enough computer could have the OG game looking better than this remaster but more likely than not would have worse performance.Speaking of mods they changed the standard way to use mods! To something far worse. Now you download mods in game and need a Bethesda account to do so. The interface for selecting the mods is the same as on the consoles(I'll get to that) and are ill fitted to navigate with a keyboard and mouse. Also using mods disables achievements.Thankfully Nexus Mods has already updated their Mod Manager to support this new version and there's already file to enable achievements on modded playthroughs.Quite honestly this version doesn't feel rushed or badly ported but its focus is clearly on updating the game to the new generation of consoles and also allowing mods to be used on them. The PC version isn't unnecessary but it is certainly less than it could/should have been.That being said this version IS 64 bit and in time should allow for more things to be done in the game especially once the Scrypt Extender gets a new version. THEN we'll have something truly special in our hands.Owners of the old version and it's DLCs were given this new version for free so I won't complain but until the mods from the old version are properly ported over and/or new mods are made that take advatange of the 64 bit executable the original game CAN look better with the right mods and will have the same content. Recommended but for newcomers stick to the old version for now. I will update this review in case this situation ever changes.Here's to another 100 hours in Skyrim

review: Product received for free. I have only played it for a little bit so i do not know everything...First off i'd like to point out that Steam/Bethesda was generous in giving this game for free to those who already have the game + all the DLCs. It made me download it immediately and try it out.From what i've seen so far is that the graphics are improved... yet only the enviroment. The rocks boulders roads trees caves etc. all look better than in the original game. It is easy to notice and it does make the game look nicer than before. HOWEVER..... that is basicly the only thing that is improved. The enviroment got an update and that is it.(I noticed the following... maybe others will notice things i didn't or disagree with me) The characters still look basicly the same... with maybe the faces being a bit smoother. Wood as in houses and wooden structures/objects still look the same or there is little improvement. Weapons/armour still look the same. Hair looks the same. No improvement when it comes to clipping (objects passing through each other.... the guy who got executed before you sunk half through the ground) No smoother gameplay... as in it is still heavily scripted and the character's dialogues still don't smoothely follow up on each other.Despite the little changes for some reason it takes up massive amounts of memory and i get lag all the time. I run Skyrim with tons of mods without a problem and here i can't run low quality normally. Not sure if that is my fault or the game not allotting memory properly.In the end it is still the exact same game. Would i play it because it got a bit of an upgrade? No i would rather play Skyrim with tons of mods than a remastered version without them. Maybe i'll check out more of the game later but for now i'll go back to the original game.I would not reccomend it but purely because there are too few changes to make a real difference. You can try it out and see for yourself but from what i have seen so far.... nah... no thanks.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Last week I was debating on buy either Legendary Edition or SE. I read the reviews of SE and saw nothing but "no new improvements" or "This version of the game is a waste! My orginal Skyrim with an ENB looks better than this!" Therefore I bought SLE. I completed this game back on the PS3 and haven't played it since. I start modding the game adding an ENB since they said it looks great added a few mods nothing game breakingLaunch the game. Crash. Close and reopen.Crash. Unclicked every mod restarted game.Crash.Deleted game. Redownloaded game. Launched game.... CRASH. !!! I sat for 2 days trying to fix this and everything I did literally helped none. I refunded my money and decide to go with SE so I can just play this game launched game... WORKED. FINALLY! Decide to download mods the exact same as it would have been on orginal.Launched game.WORKED!YES! Now I can't seem to stop playing! The 64 bit engine is MUCH more stable than the 32! Although it is fairly new there is still quite a lot of mods out that makes this game look amazing! I can't wait for the mods to be ported to SE and for the newer mods to come out! I have currently 36 mods running and I have had 0 FPS drops! I highly perfer this over the orginal Skyrim. Although if you are currently happy with your orginal Skyrim with the mods and it runs smoothly DO NOT get this! Wait till most mods have been ported over than decide then if you want to get this! Now if you are just starting to play Skyrim I highly suggest this version and no the orginal! You will get every DLC and have much better mod stabilty!Have fun!

review: Product received for free. This game keeps drawing you back. As it can be played anyway you like there is no pressure to achieve certain objectives unless you really want to. You can explore undertake crafting and travel to other areas in Skyrim. Quests give you the chance to find other areas and enhance your skills. You can also recruit an NPC to accompany you when undertaking quests and exploring. The undertaking of quests can also be taken at times that suit you and the level of advancement you have achieved. The best way to learn about the game is to walk from place to place and talk to NPCs who give advice and point you in the right direction to be able to undertake quests. While walking it give you the opportunity to collect ingredients to make up potions and of course quests also give you the opportunity to collect loot that can be sold or used to increase your ability to protect yourself. The number of mods available in this game also allows a player to set the game up to suit the playing style they decide to undertake and also add a mass of new quests and meet new characters not present in the vanilla version of the game.Load up and just enjoy one of the best RPGs available.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Everyone had that one friend who raved about Skyrim when it first came out. If you haven't played it by now just know that they were right. This is the archetypal open world fantasy RPG. The possibilities are endless. Marry a wizard princess. Hang out with some assassins. Help a talking dog. Join the modding community so you can summon some dragons. Go play Skyrim.

review: Product received for free. (Before I start the game was free for owning original)Skyrim is one of those games that never get old to most that have played it. It's always a game you can come back to. I've played it since the Xbox 360 in 2011 and the game itself is one of the most immersive I have ever played in my life (which is a big deal for me to say) and the content in this game can make you smile frown laugh shake your head in disbelief and many other emotions. You can do things that make you feel completely all powerful feel like the richest man in the world or make you feel downright diabolical. This game basically just a graphically updated verison of the original which is great for those that haven't played it yet but so so for those that have as much more was possible graphically with mods on the original. However the best way to look at this for veteran players is think of the new engine this verison is built on. The possibilties and stability of mods from the original game or completely new ones will be much easier to achieve and realize. Once again this game will become like wine and will only better with age thanks to the mods with the main game still offering 100s of hours for anyone. Overall this game will forever be among my most coveted of games that I will always recommend. Although the bugs of the old version are still present again mods already are taking care of that. One of the best things a game can do is make you feel like you're in the world itself feel like your character is you and what you do has an impact or makes you FEEL something period. And this game does that.Here's to another 5 years of Skyrim.

review: Product received for free. Pros it was free graphics kind of look better...i guess..its Skyrim. Game save did transfer over from Skyrim after a simple copy and paste into the game folder. Running a GTX970 SSC EVGA and still maintain 60fps on Ultra settings however when the game loaded a message popped up saying "high quality texture pack not supported."Cons Achievements did not transfer. I read somewhere that it said it would have different achievements. Maybe I was misinformed. But there a long list of achievemntes that are the same and did not transfer over. simple as "reach level 15" are greyed out even though I am level 32 lol. Overall I would not recommend paying full price for this game unless you have never downloaded it. Its your money though so do what you want with it. I have not experienced any of the laggy buggy gameplay that other are describing on this thread. Load times are the same and it runs smoothly...so far. Ill still play it for the minor bump in graphics. But others have said that a modded version of the previous Skyrim will run just as good or better than this one and you can get it for less money. Choice is up to you

review: Just to clarify this game is amazing If your new to this game and your thinking of getting it just do it. If your returning to this game be warned as obvious as this may be the MODS are NOT Steamworks and DO NOT support SKSE (yet) meaning there will be some time before any UI mods come out (as well as many other types of mods.) As silly as this sounds the base Skyrim UI is just terrible and makes the game for me feel like a console game. SKYUI was and still is the perfect PC Skyrim UI it made playing this on PC a dream. Again thats my opionion dont shoot me. (Also i havent checked the Nexus yet ) )If you just want this because you do like Skyrim then get it as a base game its still an absolute cracker! it looks and plays fantastic.Oh its worth mentioning i have everything cracked on ultra at 4K and i get solid 60fps. Once or twice it has dropped to around 49 but thats only during the intro when everythings going down it really didnt make a difference having sunk hours into the OG version its just nice to see it run like butter. If that matters to anyone take it or leave it. (GTX 980Ti i7 4770k)I also found it funny that the game looks realllllly nice the graphical update is 100% better but the player models still look like over cooked potatos. You'll know what i mean just by looking around in the starter cart. (Wow green trees! wow god rays! wow...um... sun tanned slapped bum faced horse thief...)PS please pardon spelling mistakes eventhough English is my native language i am terrible at it.8/10 only because of mods and player models.

review: I really like the changes for Special Edition(SE). I was trying to decide if I wanted SKSE and SkyUI from the old version but what it ultimately came down to for me was the small details added in with SE. Also I found alternatives to needing SKSE and used an older version of SkyUI. I also found plenty of mods for things I wanted changed that worked great with the new and improved Skyrim SE!Things I am loving and make it so I will never go back to the old version. The way that clouds move around the mountains now and the water now moves through the rivers The way the SunShafts/GodRays come through the trees The overall look and added immersion with the improved visuals and shadersThings I am anxiously awaiting SKSE 64 new SkyUI following SKSE 64Great game! Would recommend.

review: Product received for free. Regarding modsI have 2 000+ hours on the original Skyrim due to the unlimited possibilities of modding. While there is barely anything now I believe this will give way for a promising start to an already matured modding community. In a few years time this might possibly be even better than the current original Skyrim modding scene as the new engine packs more of a punch than the original Skyrim. Hopefully paid mods don't make a come back.Pros +Same game nothing much changed story is the same same bugs same everything physics wonky at 60fps etc+Includes all DLC+Slight graphical upgrade from original vanilla Skyrim+64bit also Alt tab works properly now+Really great potential for future modding sceneCons Why default to a controller? The graphical upgrades does not justify the framerate loss. I know plenty of mods that makes the game x100 visually more appealing and does not shed a single framerate Personally don't use it but Steam Workshop is gone Not really a con but if your a big modder like me the scene is nearly non existent right nowMy opinion on The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim Special EditionPersonally and in my own humble opinion maybe this version would have benefitted more as a "console only" title. By putting it on PC Bethesda has successfully divided the modding community as people will be making mods only for one version and exclusive on the other. Mods with inactive authors won't be able to be ported over to new Skyrim unless someone volunteers to do it. Yes most minor mods can be ported over easily but more complex script orientated or gameplay overhauls will take longer and some mod authors might not even have the incentive to port over. Correct me if I'm wrong about anything but I think I got the basic point across.

review: Product received for free. I have receied this for free due to the fact I already owned Skyrim and every DLC there was. I want to say that Skyrim Special Edition is a considerable upgrade of the original with way better graphics and enhancements in the vanilla form and now with the constant grouth of the community who keeps porting or re creating MODs from the original Skyrim into the Special Edition this is litteraly the Skyrim to play from now one. The old version will most likely become obsolete soon.There's a lot of bugfixes and waaaay more stability I experienced only bugs and/or glitches caused by my improper installation of MODs or their load order. The vanilla game works flawlessly and if you mod it well you'll have no problem whatsoever. title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Five years after the initial release Skyrim is back and better than ever. The updated graphics textures and lighting etc. is a major improvement over the original release. For those of us who spend hours modding our Elder Scrolls games it may not be immediately apparent just how much of an improvement this release actually is. Take a moment to compare the original vanilla release and this new release and you'll see for yourself. This game will only continue to improve as mods new and old are created and updated for this version of Skyrim and you will find yourself returning time and again to play.I have nominated this game for the Just Five More Minutes Steam Award as I've often found myself playing the game into the small hours of the night.If you enjoy exploring an open world in a Nordic fantasy setting then you can't go wrong with The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

This means that the ram and vram usage limitation should be gone (my own assumption).There is also better support for mods. However I still suggest getting mods from the nexus (http //www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition).

review: They tweaked the contrast darkened the game a little and added more fog. Dont be fooled.Rough content overview 2 Reviews. 1 'what they didnt do' catagory. 1 what they ed up this time catagory. ...and a few small rant chunks get over it.1 First timer.Nope. Buy the original cheaper and with more mods available. This is not even a visual upgrade.(Played at ultra)When the original version goes on sale its like $5 for game and DLC. Please dont let Bethesda think this is ok. They did nothing. Literally tossed a few cruddy assets in here dumped in lighting systems that LOOK LIKE !!!! ported to a game not designed for them.Waste of time and money.2 Free for original owners.Nope. Ditch all your mods and redownload just to get 'this'... 'this' is a joke. On ultra it is shinier. Literally. Shiny. At some points... to a stupid degree. Like.. dirt shines... en hell? Reflective shiny dirt and dirty rocks... why are people fooled by this This isnt even an upgrade they just tossed a newer gen system into an old game it doesnt work in. THE GROUND SHOULD NOT BE REFLECTING LIGHT! Especially not through all the new fog.Dont mistake higher end tech for better quality.Solid pass. No physx upgrade. Same physx issues. No controls or handling upgrade. No FOV/NewOptions/etc added. Still have to sit through the whole ing intro all over again and lighting still butchers Had s face. Still dont even know what he looks like.Thats it. Tell yourself that 64 bit will blow up in modding... what... like if has with F4? Yeah... just like that... l.. _ ..l Dont fool yourself. This is worthless and Bethesda has wasted everyones time to cash in on console mods.New issues Monkey see monkey find. No searching. They find you. AI appear to have been downgraded to simple spot and seak with no middle ground. Texture issues... like with clothing and skin showing through it. I didnt even think that was possible without mods... apparently it is. Well at least I can see my without mods now(literally through the ancient nord skirt.) Alt+tab was coded by the monkeys mentioned above. Mod thieft. Just like console mods with F4 people are stealing others mods to port over and post on Beth.net. Nexus is down because people are ing up general pop trying to port and play S SE mods. Thx a bunch s. Ever heard about 'leaving well enough alone'.Rant time Real issue here with what Bethesda has or has not done.Skyrim. Why Skyrim? Skyrim is not an old game.... relevant failure aside it didnt need an upgrade. Anything it needed was available as mods... but here is the kicker...THERE ARE TWO GAMES! AT LEAST! AT LEAST!AT LEAST!!!!!!!!!! 2 games.... that SHOULD have gotten an upgrade. Morrowind and Oblivion would have been amazeballs with a proper remaster. Or even Fallout3 would have had some benefit.Upgrading Skyrim... even if it had actually worked would have been useless anyway... come on Bethesda. I defend you for years and now you are acting like the piece of youv been called for years.

review: Product received for free. Most of the main mods have already been ported from Legendary edition and the game itself runs visibly better than Legendary. That is to say huge improvement. review: Nothing is quite as amazing as this game. In all my years of video games I never felt as connected to a video game as Skyrim. The feeling after saving the world from Alduin was visceral as .But the real game begins after you get bored. The modding community is a mixing pot of passionate software developers with a real love for the game and perverts with a real love for the game.A taboo grew where modding was cast with a shadow one of gross debauchery. There were people who would model their dragonborn with physics defying breasts and Japanese anime like art and textures. Creating such atrocities like Thomas the Tank engine Dragons and replacing the skin of all the animals in skyrim with Macho Man Randy Savage.But for me I chose to seek one the mods that specifically helped me immerse int the game. Very rarely (not true at all) will a game grab my curiosity with it s developed lore and developed landscapes. Once you learn to dive into the game and begin to focus on IMMERSION then you can finally enjoy it.*Step 1. Have a good PC Step 2. Install an ENB Audio overhaul immersive citizens texture improvements more spells cooler weapons.Step 3. You are no longer Daniel who owes thousands of dollars in student loans you are Dragonborn!Step 4. Finish all the million sidequestsStep 5. Repeat*any step with a star is a requirement and cannot be skipped.

review: Product received for free. The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim was one of my favourite games of all time. This remastered version excited me but worried me simultaneously. I was hoping the graphics would actually improve and that modding would still be an option. Mods aside the game is fantastic still and has a new beauty to it with the re work. Some people complain that the graphics didn't improve enough but I think that's complete nonsense. Adding modding into the equation I really like the new mod selection system and how it loads/manages them for you. The customisation options are splendid and I couldn't be happier with the new system aside from some old mods being harder to find. This game has had some crashing issues but nothing that can't be 'rolled out' with some updates. And if you aren't constantly quicksaving in Skyrim do you even care what happens? ( )

review: Product received for free. Alright let's get a few things straightened up here. Bethesda Game Studios / Bethesda Softworks. Bethesda Softworks decision to reintroduce paid mods to Skyrim is their problem and as far as I'm aware Bethesda Game Studio had little to do with E3 this year. Most of it was handled by Zenimax and Softworks. In such a case I do think a lot of people are hating the game studio for a sin they didn't really commit.If you're willing to get past this fact and have a rather decent computer Special Edition is Skyrim but prettier. Of course mod transferals for a lot of popular mods are complete but some of the smaller mods and the unsupported aren't. I recommend this product simply because it is not a bad game. Bethesda SOFTWORK's decision to do this to Bethesda GAME STUDIO's product is indeed moronic and a corporate failure. Let's hope this blows over like any unfortunate storm.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. TL DRDecent changes to an already good game but Bethesda deserves a thumbs down for stabbing their customers in the back... twice! If you wanna know what they really done to earn the hatred against them then make sure of reading the rest of the review. The whole problem started with Bethesda and Valve trying to introduce paid mods back in April 2015. It was a complete disaster. Valve took the whole system pretty much immediatly down due to the massive sh*tstorm the playerbase unleashed.As reaction to it both Valve and Bethesda apologized for it here's Bethesdas reaction "We have retracted our paid mod programme and do not plan to reintroduce this system again as it was heavily disliked by both users and creators alike. We at Bethesda apologise" BethesdaWe all know how that turned out right? Not only did they introduce a new paid mod programme but also they didn't really waste much time to work on it. Because with the release of Fallout 4 in November 2015 they laid the first part of the foundation of the Creation Club.By disabling achievements for modded games they made the first attempt to lower the reputation of free mods. Some might argue that there are good reasons for it because with mods you can make it a lot easier to get certain achievments and there were even mods to unlock any of them in an instant. Those arguments really have some good points but if Bethesda wanted to look after "fair play" then they should have penalized the use of the console commands too. Since they didn't it should be clear that "fair play" wasn't the intention behind this decision and the Creation Club is proof of it. Creation Club mods doesn't disable achievments.Then Skyrim SE got ported to the 64 bit engine of Fallout 4 with the same "no achievements when modding" system. And while they tinkered a bit on the graphics I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one who thinks that Skyrim SE only got ported for the Creation Club. If they really wanted to create a real Remastered Skyrim and want it to be the successor of one of their most bought games than they would've fixed at least the biggest and worst of the thousands of bugs Skyrim has. But they didn't really fix any bug. In my opinion this is one of the biggest arguments to show that it's solely a rushed port to get another game ready for every platform to bring in the "big money" with the help of the Creation Club.Some might say "But they gifted Skyrim SE to so many PC player that shows that they care for their fans."Ye... uhm... NO... not really. That's all strategy. Pretty much the same strategy Microsoft did with their Windows 10. Bethesda surely knew that there wouldn't be that much player on PC who would buy the Special Edition when there are that many mods for the old Skyrim available to mod the ever living crap out of it and make it even look far better than Skyrim SE. Because of that they gifted it to every PC player who had the "Legendary Edition" (All DLCs) of Oldrim. Like I said similar tactic as Microsoft give the new version away for free to make more money afterwards. MS does it with selling the spied data and Bethesda tries it with the Creation Club."But you don't have to buy from the Creation Club it's completely optional just ignore it."It's not really that easy. As any publisher/developer is just interested in one thing Making money period. Some others started with those greedy anti consumer tactics a while ago and guess what? Bethesda now tries to hop on that train too. They are trying to use the modding community which keeps their games alive to make money for them. As of now yes we don't have to buy anything but when we don't make a stand it can and most likely will get worse. Do you really think they keep this model of the optional Creation Club in future games? If we don't make a stand then it soon will be "Game Over" for free &amp sharable mods. If they get away with the Creation Club it will be CC mods ONLY in future games. The Creation Kit will be locked away behind the Creation Club and/or mods can only be shared via the Creation Club and the price tag Bethesda will put on it. And yes I know that's pretty much the worst case I'm describing but will you really find out if I'm right or not?One big problem is that there are many PS4 player who will buy from the Creation Club because they can't really get mods because of Sonys BS. And of course sadly there are also some naive idiots (sorry but imo they are) who believe in Bethesdas marketing lies.So I beg all of you to stand up and fight against Bethesdas greedy anti consumer tactics and STOP countering this fight just because you don't understand why we are fighting. But here I try to give an explanation to each and everyone. We need to get an even bigger sh*tstorm going than back in 2015 because this time there is no Valve who stops them and they really try to force this BS this time. Some might say we overreact but that's not the case here. Bethesda don't care at all for their fans and they stabbed us in our back for the second time now. They're just sitting it out now and are waiting that the storm of negative comments and reviews calms down. The only reaction they gave to their fans was that they lowered the price tag on the sh*tty Survival Mode in the Creation Club. But they didn't say anything about this huge and obvious sh*tstorm and that exactly tells you how much they care. The price of the Survival Mode was in close to all cases just one little part of the rants against the paid mods as a whole and how damn greedy and out of their mind Bethesda got. But no Bethesda don't say anything about the sh*tstorm and they surely wanna completely ignore it and sit it out. If they would mention or comment it in the slightest it would be all over the Internet via some news sites in no time and boy... that would be bad for them.I hope there are many who will make sure that Bethesda won't forget their bad decision until they hopefully shut down the Creation Club cancer. And if we do not prevail because of Bethesda ignoring us then do the right thing and ignore their games and don't buy any of them as long as they continue their greedy ways!Summary Bethesda f*cked with us back in 2015 apologizes when Valve pulled the string and Bethesda started immediatly to f*ck with us again disabled achievements for modded games in FO4/Skyrim SE are most likely to be sort of a bad reputation for free mods port of Skyrim to 64 bit was just another step to spread the Creation Club to more people gifting Skyrim SE to PC player is just a try to get some of them to Skyrim SE so they can possibly make more money afterwards if we don't make a stand and ignore it OR even counter those who are fighting against it will most likely result in "Creation Club mods only" Games in the future We will need everyone in the fight against this anti consumer method because there surely are some people who will buy mods Bethesda ignores the storm of negative comments/reviews and tries to sit it out. if we don't let this sh*tstorm calm down we might have still a chance against those forced paid mods system last but not least Fight with your wallet! If they don't stop ignoring our wish to take down that paid mods system than ignore Bethesdas games tooWow quite a wall of text. If I forgot something to mention then just comment and I will add it too.!!! Everyone is allowed to copy&amp paste this for your review !!!

review: Product received for free. I've played and loved Skyrim ever since it first came out logged over a thousand hours with the addition of mods and never got bored of finding new things around the game world.Skyrim Special Edition is no exception. The very second I got out of Helgen I felt like it was a new game and wanted to explore it all over again.the only two issues I see with the game as of yet is the fixable framerate and the price (though legendary edition owners get it for free) and even then its pretty reasonable for someone who has never played and wants to immerse themselves into the world. Performance is suprisingly good and the amount of effects and foliage make a huge difference.Final verdict If i'm sticking to the "out of 10" thing I'd give it a solid 9.5/10 considering how wonderfully it has been composed granted I ran into a framerate issue at the start (disabling vsync worked for me). Skyrim is still one of my all time favorites and i'll gladly put in another thousand hours!

review: Product received for free. I have never written a review for anything. Why? Because nothing was worth my precious time to do so.But here goes I love Skyrim. If you love The Elder Scrolls series Vikings snow dragons stealing horses and beating the crap out of wild animals mythic creatures good people bad people or dead people you will too! I love Skyrim SE.If you love open sandbox games with lots of lore hidden gems (lore wise and jewellery wise) good graphics and a stable 64bit engine for modding you will too! Usually this is the part of the review where readers expect a pro and con list to help them with their decision. You want one? .... off. Instead I offer you a list of random questions that I occasionally ponder while playing Skyrim Why can I only wear 1 ring if I have 10 perfectly healthy fingers? Cram at least one if not two or three rings on every goddamn finger! Toes too! Skyrim is not concerned with your well being. (Health hazards disclaimer Open furnaces. Smelting fumes. Open fire cooking and other carcinogens. Has anyone seen any hand sanitizer? Antibiotic cream and bandaids? Has anyone gotten a call from the local alchemist for the yearly influenza inoculation?) What can I do to get the people in Riverwood to like me after accidentally killing one of their chickens? Why do I marry Farkas EVERY. DAMN. TIME? Why doesn t my Housecarl clean up my place after I accidentally Fus Ro Dah d in it? It s a goddamn mess and you re at home all day anyway! I m talking to you Iona!WHERE THE DID MY HORSE GO? What are candles and torches made of seeing as they are all lit neatly in ruins no one has entered for 100s of years. Also Is it safe to eat the food you find or should you pack loperamide and antiemetics beforehand?How many cabbages would I need to carry to fully heal? Is it humanly possible to store carry and eat that many cabbages in this world or would I die of flatulence? Why would Maven threaten me with calling the Dark Brotherhood on me while I m wearing the garment that clearly shows that I m the head of the Dark Brotherhood?What s the active ingredient in moon sugar and how much do you have to consume to think you imagined someone was attacking you if you have an arrow protruding from your nether region? Dude seriously.. where is my goddamn mountain goat... uhm horse? Can I have a horse whistle? What do you mean I own 26 horses and I can t find a single one?Edit Chat quote of mine 'I am wondering if I should write a review for skyrim because it is the best thing ever apart from sex and potentially Chihuahuas.'

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. This is what's supposed to be the definitive version of Skyrim with Remastered graphics and various improvements over the original game along with coming pre installed with all addons from the original. That's not to say that this version doesn't come with it's own flaws as well. A number of old bugs from the original still remain and some new ones have been created. When I first installed the game upon release it was REALLY buggy black screen CTDs (Crashes to desktop) and could only when I did manage to get into the game there were flashy light patches everywhere and a nasty 10 15 fps.To fix this Nvidia has released a new driver update which comes with optimization support for Skyrim Special Edition. In addition going into C Users USERNAME Documents My Games Skyrim Special Edition (Or whatever it is for you) and setting the iVSyncPresentInterval value to "0" (that's zero without quotes) fixes the problems. I feel the horrible performance issues was due to Steam releasing the game a day early prior to graphics card driver support optimization being released for this game. Basically just update your drivers and disable Vsync from the game's .ini file and you should be fine.Some things to look forward to in this version The original Skyrim was running on a 32 bit engine resulting in a max of 4 GB of RAM usage for mods which was the sole reason why the game gradually became unstable the more mods you had. This version runs on a 64 bit engine holding 16 Exabytes of RAM (which is equal to 16 billion gigabytes) which means the game is more stable and is capable of carrying basically a near infinite supply of mods without crashing. So no need to worry about ridiculously long mod load lists you can indulge and bask in nearly as many mods as you like without worrying about CTDs. For those complaining about mods disabling achievements there's actually already a mod released on Nexus that disables achievement disabling due to having mods. The atrocious load times from the original game have been fixed. Expect less time waiting and more time playing Skyrim. While the original game can still at the current moment look better with ENBs (visual enhancement mods) installed players should remember that this is the BASE GAME. This how beautiful the game looks without any mods imagine the possibilities for when the modding community in this game begins to mature? With the new 64 bit engine this game's modding future looks brightly promising. Players should expect a modding community that will grow exponentially faster than the original.Can't really say the game's full price is exactly "worth it" in its current state since the modding community is still premature but if you recieved it for free might as well give it a shot. Try the above optimizations mentioned previously it may or may not help your case.

review: Along with other dedicated and slightly cultish fans of this amazing videogame series known as The Elder Scrolls it pains me to say thisI'm not going to on bethesda as Skyrim Special Edition was and still is a blessing for all console players. In bethesda's credit they have ventured and battled for the concept (now reality) of mods on console although these mods will never amount to the ubsurdity nor creativity that you can find on PC it gives dedicated fans enough to stay happy and entertained. Although i belive this is a great breakthrough they've made a grave mistake implemeting their mods system into the PC version (and obviously paid mods i am not getting into detail with this as you've probably already seen a paragraph about how this is the coming of satan). Steam workshop was thriving and although we had some hicupps everything got back into fighting form bethesda understandably want to get more users on their platform it's called making profit and growing your mailing list.Here's my problem with most reviewing this product they're focousing on mods and or bethesda although a vital part of the game for many it is not a review about the game it's about the community created content and the worsening ethics of the company behind said game if people reviewed the game for what it is the game then these reviews would be astoundingly positive although there is the far superior and better game (the original skyrim) the only thing that has changed in this game is the mods system wer can all agree on this skyrim is a special game along with the ES series this game hasn't ripped out its beauty nor stupidity thus to me it is a great game although i would pick the original release over this every day it is still worth it if you don't plan on modding your game to hell.I am reccomending this game as it is the game. Not the company not the mods nor the apparent ethical problems with this company at the moment hopefully the hate will blow over. anyway two Skyrims is always going to be better than one!

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Game in Brief /b I recieved this free as did everyone who already purchased Skyrim prior to the Special Edition release.Truth is there's only really a small handful of changes to me. The enhanced graphics the replacement of steam workshop with Bethesdas own catalogue of mods on their website and lastly the ability for console players to utilise the mods too rather than them being confined to pc players like usual.Graphics Overhaul /b The graphics are undeniably breathtaking. There's a new abundance of airy atmospheric purity when venturing through the tundra of Skyrim. The immersion doesn't just stop at textural updates either there's an increased wealth of nature both creatures and plants/trees/bushes and so on... Yet I find myself still having to use additional graphic related mods despite the magnificent landscape improvements. For example the water appeared to me as just the same as the normal version of Skyrim as did some other general aspects like the textures of indoor objects for example. Replacement Modding System /b The new mods system could be either viewed as either worse off or just the same as the traditional Steam Workshop but I can't see anyone saying that it's better. Essentially it's just replacing the Workshop with Bethesdas own catalogue of mods. This also means a change to the system of subscribing to mods before starting the game to a system where you essentially do the same except from the modifications section in the start menu before you load your game. So it's different but it's not really that different other than the fact that you have to create an account at Bethesda and start using an additional modding system when the initial one from Steam was just fine. Luckily you could just use Nexus Mod Manager which is good considering that most people used it over steam anyway for the original Skyrim.Bugs /b Finally a lot of people have told of how they are experiencing bugs glitches and so on with the game. So many players reported bugs in the questlines that it gained a reputation after a lot of the bugs ended up being quite funny in the end. I can't say I've had the misfortune (or fortune depending on how you look at it) to experience any major or even minor issues but it's still worth mentioning just in case.Conclusion /b Concluding I don't think it's really worth it for PC players when you could just carry on with the original version of Skyrim and use a combination of ENB mods to make the game look beautiful and carry on with your favourite mods in NMM ignoring the new Bethesda direct modding system. Perhaps that's why they gave it to us for free.For console however it's worth it just for the ability to mod without having to find a special type of console and so on. I just wouldn't pay too much for it to be honest.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Random CTD simulator late 2K16.Do I recomend Skyrim?Yes In matter of fact I've bought it for multiple platforms.Do I need to buy all the DLC's?All DLC's are included in this game!Should I get the Special Edition for 40 ?Hell no not in it's current state when it crashes every 10th minute.Either you buy the old version and mods for 37 (Skyrim + Add Ons Bundle) or 60 (Buying separate) or just 15 for just the game. But if you're willing to wait a bit for futher updates I'd reccomend you to do so. This is the cheap version of the entire game but you can get mods to the old version and get it to look much better.The character costumisation is exactly the same as in the other version.Conclusion DON'T BUY THIS GAME IN ITS CURRENT STATE! Yet I will still recommend this game cause I believe in the devs

review: Skyrim. 2011/11/11. I remember you well. I think both me and others forget how old you actually are. You might not be perfect but you're my baby. Your storylines can at times be shallow and rushed. You use the same pool of voice actors over and over. Your animations are lakcluster. Your combat system is simplistic. You're kinda buggy.Considering all this Skyrim is still one of my favorite games. Why is this?Skyrim spurs my imagination. It's a magical immersive open world. It was the first game I'd ever experienced to capture me in this way. I can spend my time being a backstabbing sneaky archer magic wielding cat making my Lydia haul loot I inist that we need out of dwemer ruins. I can make it my mission to collect all of Skyrim's sweetrolls and store them in my basment. I can stumble into a cave in the mountains and end up in the amazing Black Reach city. I can spend real life hours reading your books. I'm taken aback every time I load into the outside world at night and see the northern lights. I can experience the epicness of fighting Alduin and realizing how far my character has come since he accidentally saved me from the headsman's axe on that day of Last Seed in 4E201. Over the years I've collectively spent over a thousand hours in Skyrim enjoying every second and I still haven't even completed the DLC. Skyrim is FUN. It's a wonderful world full of adventure and beautiful sights waiting to be explored. What are you waiting for?

review: Product received for free. This is the best version of Skyrim that exists presently and so if that is what you're seeking you'll find it here.I find people's negative reviews to be rather odd given that this product was very upfront about what it is. This is a re release of Skyrim remastered as 64bit to enhance mod support. It allows for greater object placement greater RAM utilization in a game that historically has been very resource intensive and mod support for systems that previously did not have this option.If you previously owned Skyrim this version was given out free of charge.The game is exactly what it advertises to be and nothing more or less. They ported the game to 64 bit and fudged around with the shaders/FX. All the old bugs are still there as is the Unoffical Patch that fixes them. The negative reviews baffle me particularly the ones bemoaning the lack of an Oblivion or Morrowind remaster. Complaining that a remastered Skyrim isn't a remastered Oblivion/Morrowind is like complaining that your Hamburger isn't Spaghetti. It didn't advertise itself as spaghetti didn't promise to be spaghetti and no reasonable person would begrudge it for not being spaghetti.Reviewing the product on its own merits like a normal person all I can say is that this is Skyrim ported to 64 bit. It has enhanced resource utilization and I was given it free of charge so I'll be playing it. If you like Skyrim this is for you. If you don't then its not for you.

I personally reccomend The original Skyrim which can be found Here http //store.steampowered.com/app/72850/The_Elder_Scrolls_V_Skyrim/ The original works great and looks better too the only problem is that it does not come with the DLC but I got over that when I saw this pile of garbage.

review: Product received for free. I coping and pasting my review for the original version my review for this SE version will be at the end "The best part about this game is you can mod it so its nothing like the base game which is... mediocre. If you have havent played oblivion you were robbed of the ability to know this game is bad but its ok because its not your fault you dont know any better. Still I reccomend this game because there are so many mods there are truly limitless possiblilties While betheda tried their hardest to take the fun out of this game( magic that doesnt scale no spell creation like in oblivion/morrowind no improvement on sword combat removal of agility and hand to hand skills cant use magic and two handed swords at the same time anymore because you have to have magic in your hand now becuase it looks cooler and I cant drink 100 bottles of skooma and vault over an entire city). Moders are the true reason this game deserves to be bought.Also DLC is actually pretty good imo.Seriously dont be an idiot and use the steam workshop for mods use the nexus its 1000x better the steam workshop has about 1/50th of the mods.I give this game 1 circle out of 3"Everything I said still stands. This game currently however lacks a build of the SKSE which is a tool that modders use to create the more complex mods so right now there arent very many good mods because the majority of the ones for the original version cant be ported over yet.However if youre willing to except that than this game loads a ton faster and overall is much more sturdy so it has the potential for more and greater mods.

review: Improved better looking version of the good old Skyrim nothing more nothing less. It runs more smoothly (on my PC) the fugly blocky shadows are finally fixed the lightning effects really shine with beauty the grass and foliage looks really nice the load times are shorter. No crashes or freezes (on my PC) it was a very fluid bug free experience so far.No it still doesn't look 2016 per se (apart from some hand picked screenshots and several breathtaking locations). Yes the achievements will get disabled with mods. No it doesn't have any new content. No it isn't a completely new experience compared to playing the original Skyrim. But who cares. I don't.

review: Not recommended due to very poor graphics qualities. So bad I got motion sickness.The game uses about 30% of my cpu and gpu on ultra. Yet the graphics are very blurry turning is laggy LOD is too short FOV too narrow picking up objects makes me want to puke. And the bugs are still there e.g. Alt Tab doesn't work properly. I have played the 32 bit version heavily modded for a few thousand hours over the years on a pc built in 2010. It was a lot of fun. The modded graphics on that version are light years in front of this "special edition" version. And the gameplay is smooth and responsive even modded. So in my opinion $40 USD for this version is just not worth it. Even free it isn't worth it !Update after 20 hrs play there seems to be a major lagging problem with the game engine. Objects pop at short range bandits don't fight back but just stand there hunters pop out the roads at short range. The graphics away from the Whiterun area seem to be low res more like Fallout 3 than the old Skyrim.Update after 50 hrs play patches have improved the lagging. But objects still pop at short range. I have started installing mods with MO2. Vivid Weathers SE has improved the graphics greatly though not equal with ENB yet. All the old bugs are still there.

review: The universe of Skyrim is back! As always one of the best games released by Bethesa! The game is the exact same game except of the graphical improvements some new quests and DLCs included. I personally got this because I purchased all the DLCs for normal Skyrim (non Special Edition) before launch of the SE. I can approve that the graphics are a lot better and overall game experience is pretty much the same. I personally just moved over my savefile and continued where I left three years ago because I didn't want to re do the whole main story again and it's so much other cool quests in the game.I recommend this game if you'd like to play Skyrim with this years graphics (ish) but if you've a low end PC you can probably stick with the normal edition. The DLCs included in the Special edition are worth it I love them already I might even say I find these DLC quests even more fun than the dragon one.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: I gota say i am VERY pleased with this Remaster.People need to understand this is a Remaster not a Rerelease not a Update or a Add On.What this does is it upgrades the engine to a 64 bit more on this later adds in WAY more stability removes alot of bugs (and yes there still some in here/new ones but nothing game breaking theres already a mod on Nexus that fixes these bugs) way prettier shadows and lights and better audio from what i can tell.For those people who say theres no mods or their old mods are broken?DUH!!!!!! You Dumbasses. SKSE stands for Skyrim Special Edition not script extender anymore for this we need to wait for SKSESE Skyrim Special Edition Script Extender thats what MOST mods work off of and will NOT work until an update is out for SKSESE which will take a couple months as the workers of SE can not do anything until the game was released. Now you can use Wyrebash to convert some mods over like Skeletons like CBBE or UNP ApachiiHair and Eye mods while theres plenty of other mods that are already up on the SKSE page on NexusMods.http //www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/?Majority of these mods can be installed Via NMM without having to do anything and others you can do manually (which is always the best thing to do) I myself am running a reshade covered up ontop by a ENB texture updates and all.My SKSE looks like a gritty old film with grain effects on screen with crazy sun and weather i LOVE it way more than my Realvision i had on Skyrim. Now to the Stability. In old Skyrim you could spawn in 200 NPCs and nuke them and your PC would drop to 5 fps no matter what your rig was and possibly crash. Now though i can spawn 500 NPCS make them fight FFA style watch them fight for 20 minutes and all lay there bloodied and dead with only one person left without going under 50 fps (Note i have a 980 GTX). So where all these people are going "hurr durr my old mods dont work hurr durr its not that much better". Yes yes it really is this is like comparing Oblivion to Witcher 3 in terms of stability and visuals. Its ALOT better in almost every where especially from a modders stand point SKSE will sky rocket in performance and visuals in the next few months.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I didn't review Skyrim the first or second time I played through it in the original version and it almost goes without saying the game is fantastic.Any meaningful discussion about it has to be relative to something else be it the other Elder Scrolls games like Oblivion or Bethesda's other series like Fallout. Skyrim is clearly an evolution of the Western open world RPG genre both within the industry as a whole and specifically with its place in the Bethesda lineup.Compared to Oblivion the questing system is simpler and for me that means much improved. The leveling system is somewhat similar it's use based which is usually my favorite kind. Here the Special Edition beats the original with the inclusion of the Legendary skill feature which allows a character to reset a skill and therefore continue using it to level up. Without this it was a lot harder to improve at higher levels.Skyrim is smaller than Oblivion both in raw physical terms and in the number of NPCs and quests. Oblivion itself was smaller than Morrowind and so on. This is a sacrifice for the high fidelty we get great writing and voice acting throughout. It's almost not worth mentioning though because the number in Skyrim is still so high that any discussion about size borders on meaningless. I'd rather have fewer high quality quests anyway.Skyrim feels a bit sparser and certainly more mountainous than its contemporaries. This isn't a complaint merely an observation. It lends to the sweeping feel of the winter landscape. And the verticality is a nice change from other relatively flat maps.The Special Edition ramps up the graphics fairly significantly. The textures are equal to the high resolution pack available for the original but the lighting and particle systems are much improved. There's also the inclusion of depth of field and other blur effects that really help modernize the engine. Strangely the field of view was changed to be much tighter. This aligns the game more closely with FPSs like Call of Duty but it is an odd choice here and it threw me off initially. I think I prefer the original.Other than that there's not much to say. Skyrim is so prolific in modern gaming culture that everything from the Dragonborn to the iconic helmet to the made up phrase "Fus Ro Dah" have become common things to see on forums or in web comics. The Elder Scrolls are a beloved institution and this entry does them justice.It was really nice of Bethesda to make this version free for their fans. It makes me feel well special.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Been playing Skyrim for a long time now and modding the heck out of it. I have to say the special edition will really push forward more innovative mods in the future. Especially with skyrim running on 64bit instead of 32bit. I believe the mod load order limit is gone and also the ability to use more ram is nice. Loading times are almost cut down to 2 seconds that the previous 7 30 second loading screens. Plus it's free for those who had the legendary edition.The Special Edition seems more of a optimization rather than a remaster as most called it.Really looking forward to what the modding community has in store for us.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. It's the same game but with better graphics and bad mods. You'll have to restart your progress from the original skyrim to the special edition and the mods can only be gained from the bethesda website. No new characters no new monsters no new quests no new weapons or items no new map it's the same game.In the end the game is still a 9/10 (with some bugs) but the effort as a remaster is 4/10. The Special Edition only exists because of current consoles and PCs were just dragged along with it. I'd say it's only worth buying this if you want slightly improved graphical environment.

review: Product received for free. Rarely review games but I figured I'll review this given... the amount of dissapointment I experienced.I guess I'll start with the positives I've noticed 1 Alt + Tab no longer does that annoying windows cursour in addition to the default Skyrim one.2 The text and UI is better.Now... for the negatives.1 It honestly looks like they grabbed one of the many ENBs probably a mediocre at best one off of Nexus and slapped it over the game. 2 The textures have at most been given a minor touch up. Nothing that particularly stands out as being better either. 3 Mods disable achievements... I want to be able to apply textures and off Nexus to actually make the game look like it's actually a remake instead of this. Overall you're better off sticking to the original Skyrim and modding that to look good if you want your achievements or waiting for someone on Nexus to release a reenable achievements mod or just modding this to look good if you don't care about achievements. When they said it would be a "HD" remake I was expecting close to the level of detail Fallout 4 had in it. Sorely dissapointed and glad I owned all the DLC so I didn't have to buy this and waste money.
